Why you shouldn’t shower right after eating: Lifestyle coach reveals the impact on digestion
Lifestyle coach Luke Coutinho advises against showering immediately after meals, as it diverts blood flow from the digestive system, potentially hindering nutrient absorption and causing discomfort. Waiting 90-120 minutes post-meal or showering beforehand allows for optimal digestion, especially beneficial for those with gut sensitivities. This simple adjustment can improve energy levels and overall gut health.
Why you shouldn’t shower right after eating: Lifestyle coach reveals the impact on digestion | - Times of India Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipesfood newstravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior Carehealth newsfitnessdietmental healthcoronavirusalternative therapiesweight lossvideosdiseasesyogaNewslifestylehealth-fitnesshealth-newsWhy you shouldn’t shower right after eating: Lifestyle coach reveals the impact on digestionTrendingKidney DamageColon CancerVitamin B12 DeficiencyKidney DiseaseBeautiful Aquarium FishesFatty LiverTamannaah BhatiaOptical IllusionEgg Cooking MethodsYellow BirdsKidney DamageColon CancerVitamin B12 DeficiencyKidney DiseaseBeautiful Aquarium FishesFatty LiverTamannaah BhatiaOptical IllusionEgg Cooking MethodsYellow BirdsKidney DamageColon CancerVitamin B12 DeficiencyKidney DiseaseBeautiful Aquarium FishesFatty LiverTamannaah BhatiaOptical IllusionEgg Cooking MethodsYellow BirdsWhy you shouldn’t shower right after eating: Lifestyle coach reveals the impact on digestionTOI Lifestyle Desk / etimes.in / Updated: Aug 11, 2025, 11:21 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeLifestyle coach Luke Coutinho advises against showering immediately after meals, as it diverts blood flow from the digestive system, potentially hindering nutrient absorption and causing discomfort. Waiting 90-120 minutes post-meal or showering beforehand allows for optimal digestion, especially beneficial for those with gut sensitivities. This simple adjustment can improve energy levels and overall gut health.  Many of us enjoy a relaxing shower after a meal, thinking it helps us feel refreshed but this everyday habit could be secretly harming your digestion. Lifestyle coach Luke Coutinho, in a recent Instagram post, warned that showering immediately after eating can interfere with the body’s natural digestive process. When you eat, your body increases blood flow to the stomach, activates digestive enzymes, and works to regulate temperature for optimal breakdown of food. Stepping into the shower too soon diverts this focus, which can be especially troublesome for those dealing with bloating, acid reflux, IBS, or sluggish digestion. The fix is simple: shower before meals or wait 90–120 minutes afterward to give your gut the time it needs to do its job efficiently.Why showering after meals affects digestionBlood flow diversionWhen you eat, your body prioritises sending blood to the stomach and intestines to break down food and absorb nutrients. A hot shower draws blood toward the skin’s surface to help regulate temperature, reducing the supply to your digestive system. A cold shower can cause the opposite, narrowing blood vessels and restricting circulation. In both cases, the stomach gets less support, slowing digestion and potentially causing discomfort.Greater impact on sensitive gutsPeople with existing gut health problems, such as gastritis, IBS, chronic acidity, or constipation are more likely to feel the negative effects. Disrupting digestion early can trigger bloating, heaviness, or acid reflux, making recovery from gut issues more difficult.Temperature regulation interferenceDigestion slightly increases your body’s core temperature. Sudden exposure to very hot or cold water forces your system to shift focus toward temperature control instead of digestion. Over time, this repeated interference could lead to poor nutrient absorption and inflammation.How to adjust your shower habits for better digestionTo protect your digestive health, it’s worth making a few simple changes to your shower routine. Ideally, take a shower before meals, especially before heavy lunches or dinners, so your body can focus entirely on breaking down food afterward. If showering before eating isn’t possible, wait at least 90–120 minutes after a meal. This window gives your stomach and intestines time to process food, release enzymes, and absorb nutrients without interference. Even if you don’t have gut issues, limiting post-meal showers to occasional situations is wise. Making this adjustment not only supports digestion but also helps maintain steady energy levels, reduces the risk of bloating, and promotes overall gut health in the long run.Benefits of waiting before showeringBetter nutrient absorption, uninterrupted blood flow ensures your body uses vitamins and minerals effectively.Reduced post-meal fatigue, avoiding a shower right after eating can help you feel less sluggish and more alert.Improved metabolism, a smoother digestive process supports balanced energy and weight management.How to make the habit change easyPlan your schedule so you shower in the morning before breakfast or later in the day well after meals.After workouts, cool down first and wait before eating or showering to avoid overlapping stress on digestion.Use the waiting period after meals for light activity such as walking, gentle stretching, or reading, these can actually enhance digestion.Summary table: Shower timing and digestionHabitRecommended ChangeWhy It HelpsShowering immediately after mealsWait 90–120 minutesKeeps blood flow focused on digestionLong hot showers post-mealReduce temperature or delayPrevents excessive vasodilationCold showers right after eatingDelay until digestion startsAvoids blood vessel constrictionShowering before eatingMaintain as a habitPrepares the body for smooth digestionShowering after meals may seem harmless, but as Luke Coutinho points out, it can subtly slow down your digestion and reduce gut health efficiency over time. This is especially important for people with sensitive digestive systems. By making a simple change, showering before meals or waiting at least 90–120 minutes afterward, you can support better nutrient absorption, reduce digestive discomfort, and keep your energy levels steady. Sometimes, it’s these small, mindful adjustments that deliver the biggest long-term health benefits.Also read| Childhood obesity linked to colon cancer risk: Why parents should take early weight gain seriouslyAbout the AuthorTOI Lifestyle DeskThe TOI Lifestyle Desk is a dynamic team of dedicated journalists who, with unwavering passion and commitment, sift through the pulse of the nation to curate a vibrant tapestry of lifestyle news for The Times of India readers. At the TOI Lifestyle Desk, we go beyond the obvious, delving into the extraordinary. Consider us your lifestyle companion, providing a daily dose of inspiration and information. Whether you're seeking the latest fashion trends, travel escapades, culinary delights, or wellness tips, the TOI Lifestyle Desk is your one-stop destination for an enriching lifestyle experience.Read MoreEnd of ArticleFollow Us On Social Media Visual Stories   PreviousSaniya Iyappan steals the spotlight with her graceEntertainmentCarrie Coon’s secret weapon on TV? Boost liver function with this gut-friendly no-bake date bar supporting overall wellness; gastroenterologist shares easy homemade recipe
Dr. Joseph Salhab shares a recipe for no-bake date bars. These bars are a healthy alternative to store-bought sweets. They are rich in fibre, healthy fats, and antioxidants. The key ingredients include Medjool dates, nut butter, almonds, pistachios, and dark chocolate. The recipe involves layering these ingredients and chilling. These bars support digestive health, liver function, and sustained energy.
Boost liver function with this gut-friendly no-bake date bar supporting overall wellness; gastroenterologist shares easy homemade recipe | - Times of India Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipesfood newstravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior Carehealth newsfitnessdietmental healthcoronavirusalternative therapiesweight lossvideosdiseasesyogaNewslifestylehealth-fitnesshealth-newsBoost liver function with this gut-friendly no-bake date bar supporting overall wellness; gastroenterologist shares easy homemade recipeTrendingKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesBoost liver function with this gut-friendly no-bake date bar supporting overall wellness; gastroenterologist shares easy homemade recipeTOI Lifestyle Desk / etimes.in / Updated: Aug 11, 2025, 15:23 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeDr. Joseph Salhab shares a recipe for no-bake date bars. These bars are a healthy alternative to store-bought sweets. They are rich in fibre, healthy fats, and antioxidants. The key ingredients include Medjool dates, nut butter, almonds, pistachios, and dark chocolate. The recipe involves layering these ingredients and chilling. These bars support digestive health, liver function, and sustained energy.  Craving something sweet but don’t want to derail your healthy eating plan? No-bake date bars are the perfect solution — a naturally sweet, nutrient-rich snack that’s quick to prepare and loaded with health benefits. Recently, gastroenterologist Dr Joseph Salhab shared his recipe for this wholesome dessert on Instagram, highlighting how it can be both gut-friendly and liver-supportive.By combining dates, almonds, pistachios, and dark chocolate, this recipe delivers a satisfying treat that’s high in fibre, healthy fats, and antioxidants, without the need for refined sugar or baking.Signs that all is not well with your liverWhy no-bake date bars are a healthier dessert choice; gastroenterologists explainsMost store-bought sweets are loaded with processed sugar, preservatives, and unhealthy fats. Date-based bars, on the other hand, offer a more natural alternative.Dates provide prebiotic fibre, which feeds the beneficial bacteria in your gut, helping maintain digestive health.Nuts such as almonds and pistachios supply healthy fats, protein, and essential micronutrients like vitamin E, magnesium, and zinc.Dark chocolate (70% cocoa or higher) is rich in flavonoids, powerful antioxidants that may improve heart and liver function.Dr Salhab points out that this combination not only satisfies cravings but also supports overall wellness, making these bars suitable as a snack or dessert.No-bake-date bars: Key ingredients and their nutritional benefitsMedjool dates Medjool dates are naturally sweet, eliminating the need for added sugar. They are a rich source of fibre, potassium, magnesium, and antioxidants that help regulate digestion, support energy production, and protect against oxidative stress.Nut butter Nut butters like almond or peanut butter add a creamy texture and are packed with monounsaturated fats that promote heart health. They also provide protein for satiety and muscle repair.Almonds and Pistachios Both almonds and pistachios are excellent sources of healthy fats, plant protein, vitamin E, and minerals. These nutrients support liver detoxification and help keep cholesterol levels balanced.Dark Chocolate Choosing 70% cocoa or higher ensures your chocolate is rich in flavonoids, which can help reduce inflammation, improve blood flow, and protect liver cells from damage.No-bake date bars recipe at home: Step-by-step processStep 1 – Prepare the baseRemove the pits from approximately 14 Medjool dates. Line a baking tin with parchment paper and press the dates into an even, flat layer to form the base.Step 2 – Add the creamy layerSpread ¼ cup of your favourite nut butter evenly over the date base. This acts as a binding layer while adding a smooth, rich flavour.Step 3 – Add crunch with nutsSprinkle two handfuls of almonds and one handful of pistachios over the nut butter. You can lightly crush them for an even texture or keep them whole for extra crunch.Step 4 – Melt the chocolateMelt 250g of vegan dark chocolate (preferably 70%+ cocoa) over low heat or using a double boiler. Pour the melted chocolate over the nut layer and smooth it out.Step 5 – Chill until setPlace the tin in the fridge for about 40 minutes, or until the chocolate has fully hardened.Step 6 – Slice and enjoyCut into bars of your preferred size. Store in an airtight container in the fridge and enjoy whenever you need a healthy snack.Storage tips for no-bake date bars freshnessFor maximum freshness and texture, keep your no-bake date bars in the refrigerator. The cold setting ensures the chocolate remains firm, and the nuts stay crisp. They can last up to 10–14 days when stored properly.Health benefits of eating date barsSupports digestive health – High fibre content aids digestion and promotes a healthy gut microbiome.Boosts liver function – Healthy fats and antioxidants assist in liver detoxification.Provides sustained energy – Balanced combination of carbs, fats, and protein keeps you fuller for longer.Reduces sugar cravings – Naturally sweetened with dates, reducing dependency on refined sugar.Also Read | She lost 140 kg without surgery or supplements—now a rare disease has turned her scars into a symbol of strengthAbout the AuthorTOI Lifestyle DeskThe TOI Lifestyle Desk is a dynamic team of dedicated journalists who, with unwavering passion and commitment, sift through the pulse of the nation to curate a vibrant tapestry of lifestyle news for The Times of India readers. At the TOI Lifestyle Desk, we go beyond the obvious, delving into the extraordinary. Consider us your lifestyle companion, providing a daily dose of inspiration and information. Whether you're seeking the latest fashion trends, travel escapades, culinary delights, or wellness tips, the TOI Lifestyle Desk is your one-stop destination for an enriching lifestyle experience.Read MoreEnd of ArticleFollow Us On Social Media Visual Stories   Previous10 animals that can survive intense radiationLifestyleHow to make natural hair colour using tea and coffeeLifestyleDivyanka Tripathi’s top 10 stylish must-have lookstv9 heart-healthy foods that cut attack and stroke riskLifestyleSaniya Iyappan steals the spotlight with her graceEntertainmentCarrie Coon’s secret weapon on TV? Planning to Study in the U.S.? Here’s everything student travellers need to know from visa guidelines to new changes
In 2025, the U.S. implemented significant policy shifts impacting international students. These changes include mandatory public social media profiles for visa applicants, stricter vetting processes, and potential alterations to authorized stay calculations. Applicants should maintain clean online records, apply early, and stay updated through official government websites to navigate these evolving regulations.
Planning to Study in the U.S.? Here’s everything student travellers need to know from visa guidelines to new changes | - Times of India Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshiptravelHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipesfood newshome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior Carenewsadventureshotelsthings to dodestinationsNewslifestyletravelthings-to-doPlanning to Study in the U.S.? Here’s everything student travellers need to know from visa guidelines to new changesTrendingKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesPlanning to Study in the U.S.? Here’s everything student travellers need to know from visa guidelines to new changesetimes.in / Updated: Aug 11, 2025, 16:42 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeIn 2025, the U.S. implemented significant policy shifts impacting international students. These changes include mandatory public social media profiles for visa applicants, stricter vetting processes, and potential alterations to authorized stay calculations. Applicants should maintain clean online records, apply early, and stay updated through official government websites to navigate these evolving regulations.  U.S.is home to some reputed universities in the world and has been attracting global students for a long time now. However, in 2025 there have been some major policy shifts that have impacted the education industry as a whole. The U.S. policy makers have made a lot of changes. From making social media accounts public and pausing and resuming visa interviews to offering fixed-term eligibility under proposal, and increasing visa fees, the changes are endless and confusing too.So let’s try to understand the new changes:Make Social Media Public Amid several ongoing changes, the U.S. asked students wanting to study in American universities to make their social media profiles public because public persona matters. The new change was implemented from June 18, 2025. So now, applicants for F (academic), M (vocational), and J (exchange) visas should submit their social media accounts and set their accounts on public mode. The officers will check and scrutinise posts and other shared content of the applicants. This year, the federal government updated visa vetting and processing policies. Let’s have a look at why it matters and how is it going to impact students:The new changesThe Department of State in 2025 announced the plans of expanding visa screening. It very clearly mentioned the applicants’ online presence matter to the ‘getting whole visa’ process calling it a part of consular vetting. The Department called it an “expanded screening and vetting” process. The Department of State also updated its interview-waiver guidance. It changed to which applicants may be eligible for an in-person interview waiver. The Department also narrowed categories eligible for waiver in several cases. It means that more visa applicants should expect to attend an in-person interview unless they meet the specific waiver criteria. How will these changes impact students?Increased documentation and strict review: The new changes mean more documentations and a strict review process. The reviewers can request more personal information. They can also look beyond transcripts and bank statements and survey the applicant’s public online history and activity. More in-person questions during the interview: With the new interview-waiver rules, applicants should expect to attend consular interviews. Expect delays. Expect changes to authorized stay: If U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) finalises a fixed-term admission rule, the way students’ authorized stay is calculated would also change in future. It will affect program planning, transfers, and some employment authorizations tied to enrollment length. This is a significant move as it can change the “duration of status” system—where F visas remain valid as long as students maintain course enrollment.What current applicants/students must keep in mindKeep checking official sites only: The potential applicants must keep themselves updated with current changes on the official websites of the State Department, DHS/ICE (SEVP), and USCIS. These pages are for authoritative updates rather than unofficial commentary. Official pages have guidance, timelines, and eligibility rules as well. Do not trust any other website. Keep your record clean: Now that it is mandatory to keep your social media profile open, it is necessary for applicants to keep their record clean and monitor their online presence. Also remember that officials will only believe public information and official records.Apply early and book interviews: It is important to maintain the timeline. Apply early and book interviews as there are higher chances of required in-person interviews. Schedule embassy or consulate appointments the moment you get your Form I-20 or DS-2019. Allow buffer time: Keep extra or buffer time for program completion and other administrative steps. Keep copies of all documents and paperwork. Now that U.S. agencies are more concerned about vetting and tightening the conditions, expect delays and keep extra time and other options ready. These changes are official and mentioned on DHS/SEVP, and USCIS guidance. Keep in touch with your universities who can offer better explanations and guidance. (Official sources used here include: U.S. Department of State, Department of Homeland Security, ICE SEVP (SEVIS and program guidance), and USCIS (student classifications and employment rules).End of ArticleFollow Us On Social Media Visual Stories   Previous10 quotes on marriages by Swami Premanand Ji MaharajLifestyleSharvari Wagh brings charm to every pink detailEntertainment10 animals that can survive intense radiationLifestyleHow to make natural hair colour using tea and coffeeLifestyleDivyanka Tripathi’s top 10 stylish must-have lookstv9 heart-healthy foods that cut attack and stroke riskLifestyleSaniya Iyappan steals the spotlight with her graceEntertainmentCarrie Coon’s secret weapon on TV? 5 style lessons to learn from cricketer Shubman Gill
From airport runs to ad campaigns, his wardrobe choices tell us one thing, Shubman knows the game when it comes to style just as much as he does cricket. Here are five fashion lessons to take straight from the captain’s playbook.
Shubman Gill: 5 style lessons to learn from Indian test cricket captain Shubman Gill Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipstyleHealth+visual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipesfood newstravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior Careceleb stylestyle guidebuzzdesignersshowstimes luxuryvideosdesigner directoryNewslifestylefashionstyle-guide5 style lessons to learn from Indian test cricket captain Shubman GillTrendingKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest Countries5 style lessons to learn from Indian test cricket captain Shubman GillETimes.in /  Aug 11, 2025, 16:10 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeFollow us 1/7One of the most stylish Indian cricketersShubman Gill might be making headlines for his explosive cover drives and steely temperament on the pitch, but off it, he’s quickly becoming one of India’s most photographed and most stylish, young sports stars. If Virat Kohli was the poster boy for sporty-meets-slick dressing in the last decade, Gill is the Gen-Z evolution: a blend of quiet luxury, streetwear confidence, and just the right amount of boyish charm.From airport runs to ad campaigns, his wardrobe choices tell us one thing, Shubman knows the game when it comes to style just as much as he does cricket. Here are five fashion lessons to take straight from the captain’s playbook.by TOI Lifestyle Desk 2/7Master the imnimalist athleisureAthleisure might feel like old news, but Gill’s approach keeps it fresh. He gravitates towards clean joggers, crisp crew-neck tees, fitted track jackets, and statement sneakers but with a muted palette. No screaming neons, no over-the-top graphics - just carefully chosen, well-fitted pieces. Think Rahul Khanna’s subtle elegance meets KL Rahul’s sporty edge.The takeaway: Your gym wear can double as your casualwear if you keep it neutral, fitted, and polished.3/7Invest in statement jacketsWhether it’s a bomber in deep forest green, a varsity jacket with bold lettering, or a tailored overcoat for winter tours abroad, Shubman treats jackets like sartorial punctuation marks. They finish his outfit with personality, much like Ranbir Kapoor’s off-duty looks or even David Beckham’s classic layering game.The takeaway: A good jacket doesn’t just keep you warm, it can carry an entire look.4/7Keep denim simple but sharpGill avoids the trap of over-distressed or overly baggy jeans. His go-to? Mid- to dark-wash denims with a straight or slim fit, paired with either a tucked-in shirt for a slightly retro vibe or a hoodie for casual comfort. The fit is never sloppy, more Shahid Kapoor’s tailored casuals than anything grungy.The takeaway: A well-fitted pair of jeans can last you seasons, both in durability and relevance.5/7Embrace monochrome momentsFrom head-to-toe black at the airport to all-white for summer outings, Shubman understands the power of a single-colour statement. It’s sleek, elongating, and always photogenic. In fact, one could argue it’s his version of a “uniform,” much like how Anand Ahuja built his signature sneaker-with-suit look.The takeaway: Don’t fear monochrome, it’s not boring if you mix textures and tones.6/7​Accessorise with restraintWhile some sports stars pile on chains, caps, and oversized shades, Gill opts for a more balanced approach. A single luxury watch, a subtle cap, or a pair of aviators, never all at once. His accessories are functional yet aspirational, much like the way Hrithik Roshan styles his off-duty looks.The takeaway: Let accessories enhance, not overwhelm, your outfit.7/7​Bonus lesson - grooming mattersIt’s impossible to talk about Shubman Gill’s style without mentioning his grooming. The always-on-point fade, the occasional stubble, and skin that somehow always looks camera-ready, it’s the cricketing equivalent of a red-carpet prep. Like David Warner said about cricket, “Preparation is everything,” and in Gill’s case, that includes his hair and skin game.Shubman Gill is proof that you don’t have to be in Bollywood to have a blockbuster wardrobe. His style is approachable yet aspirational, a mix of pieces you can find on the high street and the occasional big-ticket splurge. He isn’t trying too hard, but he’s paying attention and in fashion, much like cricket, that’s how you win the match.Whether you are a cricket fan or just looking for some wardrobe cues, consider Gill your new style captain. And remember: sometimes the most stylish move is knowing when to play it safe and when to take a risk, on the field and in your closet.Follow Us On Social Media Visual Stories   PreviousSharvari Wagh brings charm to every pink detailindia10 animals that can survive intense radiationindia10 Indian states with maximum number of National ParkstravelHow to make natural hair colour using tea and coffeeindiaDivyanka Tripathi’s top 10 stylish must-have looksindia​How to make dhaba-style Egg Curry at home​Food9 heart-healthy foods that cut attack and stroke riskindiaSaniya Iyappan steals the spotlight with her graceindiaCarrie Coon’s secret weapon on TV? What is ‘Arbi’ called in english? Know how it supports your heart, gut, and overall health
Arbi, or taro root, a versatile vegetable enjoyed worldwide, offers a creamy texture and nutty flavor. Beyond its taste, arbi is packed with fiber, potassium, and antioxidants, promoting digestive and heart health while boosting immunity. Enjoy it boiled, roasted, or in curries for sustained energy and strong bones. Remember to cook it well to eliminate calcium oxalate crystals.
What is ‘Arbi’ called in english? Know how it supports your heart, gut, and overall health | - Times of India Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipfood newsHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipestravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior CareNewslifestylefood-newsWhat is ‘Arbi’ called in english? Know how it supports your heart, gut, and overall healthTrendingKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesWhat is ‘Arbi’ called in english? Know how it supports your heart, gut, and overall healthTOI Lifestyle Desk / etimes.in /  Aug 11, 2025, 16:09 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeArbi, or taro root, a versatile vegetable enjoyed worldwide, offers a creamy texture and nutty flavor. Beyond its taste, arbi is packed with fiber, potassium, and antioxidants, promoting digestive and heart health while boosting immunity. Enjoy it boiled, roasted, or in curries for sustained energy and strong bones. Remember to cook it well to eliminate calcium oxalate crystals.  If you’ve ever come across the word arbi and wondered what it means, you’re not alone. Arbi, known in English as taro root, is a starchy, underground vegetable enjoyed across Asia, Africa, and the Caribbean. Though it looks like a small, brown, fuzzy potato on the outside, it holds a creamy texture and nutty flavour inside that makes it incredibly versatile in the kitchen. Beyond taste, arbi offers numerous health benefits, making it a smart addition to your diet. Whether boiled, roasted, or added to curries, this humble root has far more to offer than meets the eye.What is arbi (Taro root)Arbi or taro root is a starchy tuber that grows underground and has been enjoyed by cultures worldwide for centuries. Its pale, creamy flesh and nutty flavour make it a versatile ingredient that can be boiled, fried, mashed, or added to stews. But what makes arbi special isn’t just the taste, it’s the range of health benefits packed inside this root.Why you should add arbi to your plate: Health benefits that matter1. Aids digestive health: One of the main benefits of arbi is its high fibre content, which helps maintain healthy digestion. Fibre adds bulk to stools, promoting regular bowel movements and preventing constipation. A well-functioning digestive system also supports better nutrient absorption and reduces the risk of digestive disorders.2. Supports heart health: Arbi is a good source of potassium, a mineral essential for maintaining healthy blood pressure levels. Potassium helps balance the effects of sodium and eases tension in blood vessel walls, reducing the risk of hypertension and heart disease. Eating potassium-rich foods like arbi can be an effective part of heart-friendly dietary habits.3. Boost your immunity: Thanks to antioxidants found in arbi, your body gets an extra shield against harmful free radicals. This support means your immune system can work more effectively to keep common illnesses at bay.4. Steady energy for your busy day: Unlike sugary snacks that give you a quick rush and then a crash, arbi provides slow-releasing energy. This means you’ll feel energised for longer, perfect for powering through work, study, or workouts.5. Strong bones and muscles: Arbi also contains minerals like magnesium and calcium that are essential for bone strength and muscle function. Eating arbi regularly may support your mobility and overall body strength as you age.6. Fighting inflammation naturally: Chronic inflammation is linked to many health problems, but nature offers help in arbi. Some compounds in taro root have anti-inflammatory properties, which might help reduce discomfort and protect your body long-term.How to enjoy arbiThe great thing about arbi is that it’s incredibly versatile. Here are some ways you can enjoy it:Boiled or steamed: Simply cook until tender and season with salt and herbs for a comforting side dish.Taro chips: Slice thinly and fry or bake for a crunchy snack that rivals regular potato chips.Curries and stews: Add chunks of arbi to your favourite curries or soups to soak up all the spices and flavours.Mashed arbi: Like mashed potatoes, but with a nuttier taste- try mixing with butter and garlic for a creamy delight.Soups: Add it to broths for a hearty texture and subtle sweetness.Important tips: What you need to know before eating arbiRaw arbi contains tiny needle-like crystals called calcium oxalate, which can irritate your mouth or throat. That’s why always cook it well before eating. Boiling, steaming, or frying will break down these crystals and make it safe and delicious.If you have a history of kidney stones, it’s best to eat arbi in moderation because of its oxalate content.Also read | Is eating avocados daily safe? Kidney cleansing and detoxing myths: What you should know
Kidney detoxes are popular, but the kidneys naturally filter blood and remove waste. Detox teas and juices lack scientific support and may harm kidney function. While hydration is important, excessive water intake can strain kidneys. A balanced diet, regular exercise, and managing underlying conditions are proven ways to support kidney health.
Kidney cleansing and detoxing myths: What you should know | - Times of India Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipesfood newstravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior Carehealth newsfitnessdietmental healthcoronavirusalternative therapiesweight lossvideosdiseasesyogaNewslifestylehealth-fitnesshealth-newsKidney cleansing and detoxing myths: What you should knowTrendingKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney cleansing and detoxing myths: What you should knowTOI Lifestyle Desk / etimes.in /  Aug 11, 2025, 16:00 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeKidney detoxes are popular, but the kidneys naturally filter blood and remove waste. Detox teas and juices lack scientific support and may harm kidney function. While hydration is important, excessive water intake can strain kidneys. A balanced diet, regular exercise, and managing underlying conditions are proven ways to support kidney health.  Kidney detoxes and cleansing routines have become increasingly popular, often promoted as quick solutions to improve kidney health, remove toxins, or boost overall wellness. From herbal teas to juice fasts, many of these methods promise results that sound too good to be true. The truth is that your kidneys are already excellent at detoxifying your body without any special interventions. Misunderstanding how the kidneys work can lead to unnecessary or even harmful health practices. Falling for these myths may not only waste your time and money but also put your kidney health at risk.What kidney detox myths get wrong about your healthMyth 1: Your kidneys need regular cleansingOne of the most widespread health myths is the idea that your kidneys need to be cleansed or flushed with specific drinks or diets. In reality, healthy kidneys continuously filter your blood, remove waste products, and balance your body's fluids and electrolytes. They do this naturally and efficiently. Unless your kidneys are damaged or diseased, they do not require any external cleansing. The best way to support them is through good nutrition, proper hydration, and regular health checks.Myth 2: Detox teas and juices can repair or improve kidney functionDetox teas, juices, and supplements often claim to remove toxins or enhance kidney function, but these claims are not supported by scientific evidence. Many of these products are unregulated and may contain high levels of certain herbs or diuretics that can stress the kidneys rather than help them. In some cases, they may lead to dehydration or mineral imbalances. If you have any kidney condition, these types of detoxes may do more harm than good.Myth 3: Drinking more water always helps cleanse the kidneysWhile staying hydrated is important for kidney function, more water is not always better. Drinking too much water can dilute essential salts in the body and place strain on the kidneys. People with healthy kidneys should aim to drink according to their body's needs, which can vary based on activity level, environment, and individual health conditions. For most people, drinking when thirsty and monitoring the colour of urine is enough to stay well hydrated.Myth 4: A kidney cleanse helps remove kidney stonesSome believe that consuming large amounts of citrus juice or herbal drinks can flush out kidney stones or prevent their formation. While drinking water and maintaining a balanced diet can help prevent stones in some cases, a true kidney cleanse will not dissolve or remove existing stones. Treatment for kidney stones depends on their size and type and often requires medical supervision. Relying on home remedies could delay proper care and increase the risk of complications.What really supports your kidney healthThe kidneys thrive when you take care of your overall health. The following lifestyle choices are proven to support kidney function:Eat a balanced diet that is low in sodium and processed foodsLimit your intake of red meat and animal fatsStay physically active and maintain a healthy weightAvoid smoking and limit alcohol consumptionManage underlying conditions such as high blood pressure and diabetesStay hydrated without overdoing itAvoid overuse of painkillers and unnecessary supplementsThese habits can help protect your kidneys from damage and reduce your risk of developing chronic kidney disease.Also read | Urine colour and kidney problems: Signs you shouldn’t ignoreAbout the AuthorTOI Lifestyle DeskThe TOI Lifestyle Desk is a dynamic team of dedicated journalists who, with unwavering passion and commitment, sift through the pulse of the nation to curate a vibrant tapestry of lifestyle news for The Times of India readers. Is eating avocados daily safe? The possible allergies and digestive side effects you must know
While avocados are celebrated for their health benefits, they can trigger allergic reactions, especially in those with latex allergies. Overconsumption may lead to digestive issues and weight gain due to their high calorie and fiber content. Avocados can also interfere with blood-thinning medications because of their vitamin K levels and potentially trigger migraines in susceptible individuals.
Is eating avocados daily safe? The possible allergies and digestive side effects you must know | - Times of India Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipfood newsHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipestravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior CareNewslifestylefood-newsIs eating avocados daily safe? The possible allergies and digestive side effects you must knowTrendingKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesIs eating avocados daily safe? The possible allergies and digestive side effects you must knowTOI Lifestyle Desk / etimes.in /  Aug 11, 2025, 16:00 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeWhile avocados are celebrated for their health benefits, they can trigger allergic reactions, especially in those with latex allergies. Overconsumption may lead to digestive issues and weight gain due to their high calorie and fiber content. Avocados can also interfere with blood-thinning medications because of their vitamin K levels and potentially trigger migraines in susceptible individuals.  Avocados are a popular superfood known for their creamy texture and rich nutrient profile, including healthy fats, fibre, and vitamins. However, despite their benefits, avocados can cause side effects in some people. Allergic reactions, particularly among those with latex allergies, are common. Overconsumption may lead to digestive issues like bloating and gas, especially in individuals with sensitive stomachs or IBS. Due to their high calorie content, excessive intake can contribute to weight gain. Avocados also contain vitamin K, which may interfere with blood-thinning medications. Additionally, they can trigger migraines in susceptible individuals. Eating avocados in moderation and consulting a healthcare provider is advisable.Risks and side effects of eating avocados daily1. Allergic reactionsSome individuals may experience allergic reactions after consuming avocados. Symptoms can range from mild itching and skin rashes to more severe reactions like breathing difficulties or anaphylaxis. People with latex allergies are at a higher risk of developing an avocado allergy due to cross-reactivity .From Avocado to Zinc: Key nutrients for healthy skin and how to get them2. Digestive issuesAvocados are high in fibre, which is beneficial for gut health. However, consuming them in excess may cause bloating, gas, or stomach cramps. Individuals with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) need to exercise extra caution .3. High-calorie contentWhile avocados contain healthy fats, they are also calorie-dense. Overeating can lead to weight gain, particularly for individuals managing their calorie intake. If you are mindful of your weight, it's best to enjoy avocados in moderation .4. Interaction with medicationsAvocados contain vitamin K, which plays a crucial role in blood clotting. For individuals on blood-thinning medications like warfarin, consuming avocados in large amounts can interfere with the medication's effectiveness .5. Migraine triggersAvocados are a source of the amino acid tyrosine, which naturally breaks down into tyramine in the body. High levels of tyramine can trigger headaches and elevate blood pressure, potentially leading to migraines .6. Latex-fruit syndromeIndividuals with latex allergies may also be sensitive to avocados. This condition, known as latex-fruit syndrome, can cause symptoms ranging from mild itching to more severe reactions .7. Mouth irritationSome people may experience mild oral symptoms, such as itching or tingling in the mouth, when consuming avocados. This can be associated with cross-reactivity with pollen allergens .8. Foodborne illness riskLike any other fresh produce, avocados can sometimes carry harmful bacteria, such as Salmonella or E. coli. Contamination can occur if avocados are handled improperly, left at unsafe temperatures, or not washed thoroughly before consumption .Frequently Asked QuestionsQ1: Can avocados cause allergic reactions?Yes, some individuals may experience allergic reactions to avocados, ranging from mild itching to severe anaphylaxis, particularly those with latex allergies.Q2: Are avocados high in calories?Yes, avocados are calorie-dense due to their healthy fat content. Overconsumption can lead to weight gain if not balanced with other dietary components.Q3: Can avocados interact with medications?Avocados contain vitamin K, which can interfere with blood-thinning medications like warfarin. It's essential to monitor your intake if you're on such medications.Q4: Are avocados safe for people with IBS?Individuals with IBS should consume avocados in moderation, as their high fibre content can cause digestive discomfort in some people.Q5: Can avocados cause foodborne illnesses?Improper handling and storage of avocados can lead to contamination with harmful bacteria, posing a risk of foodborne illnesses.Also read | Is multigrain, zero maida bread really better for your blood sugar levels? Know it’s impact on sugar levelsAbout the AuthorTOI Lifestyle DeskThe TOI Lifestyle Desk is a dynamic team of dedicated journalists who, with unwavering passion and commitment, sift through the pulse of the nation to curate a vibrant tapestry of lifestyle news for The Times of India readers. Can VitaminB12 deficiency cause nerve damage? Here’s what you need to know
Vitamin B12 is important for nerve health. Low levels can cause tingling and numbness. It may also lead to balance problems and memory loss. If not treated, nerve damage can become permanent. Vegans and older adults are at higher risk. Blood tests can check B12 levels. Treatment includes supplements or injections. Early action is key to prevent lasting harm.
Can VitaminB12 deficiency cause nerve damage? Here’s what you need to know | - Times of India Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipesfood newstravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior Carehealth newsfitnessdietmental healthcoronavirusalternative therapiesweight lossvideosdiseasesyogaNewslifestylehealth-fitnesshealth-newsCan VitaminB12 deficiency cause nerve damage? Here’s what you need to knowTrendingKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesCan VitaminB12 deficiency cause nerve damage? Here’s what you need to knowTOI Lifestyle Desk / etimes.in / Updated: Aug 11, 2025, 15:22 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeVitamin B12 is important for nerve health. Low levels can cause tingling and numbness. It may also lead to balance problems and memory loss. If not treated, nerve damage can become permanent. Vegans and older adults are at higher risk. Blood tests can check B12 levels. Treatment includes supplements or injections. Early action is key to prevent lasting harm.  Vitamin B12 plays a vital role in maintaining the health of the nervous system, including the brain, nerves, and spinal cord. A deficiency in this essential nutrient can lead to a range of neurological symptoms, such as tingling, numbness, poor coordination, memory loss, and mood changes. If left untreated, prolonged vitamin B12 deficiency may result in irreversible nerve damage. This is particularly concerning as neurological symptoms can appear before signs of anaemia. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent long-term complications. Regular monitoring and a balanced diet or supplementation can help maintain healthy B12 levels and protect nerve health.What is Vitamin B12: Signs of deficiency that affects nerve healthVitamin B12 (also known as cobalamin) helps produce red blood cells, supports DNA synthesis, and plays a key role in maintaining healthy nerve cells. It’s naturally found in animal-based foods such as meat, fish, eggs, and dairy. People following plant-based diets, or those with medical conditions affecting absorption, are most at risk of developing a deficiency.Vitamin B12 rich foods for vegetarian dietVitamin B12 deficiency can lead to neurological symptoms even before blood levels drop enough to cause anaemia. Common nerve-related signs include:Tingling or numbness in the hands, feet, or legsBalance issues or frequent fallsWeakness in musclesMemory loss or difficulty concentratingMood changes, including depression or irritabilityBurning sensations in extremitiesCoordination problems while walkingThese symptoms may begin subtly but can worsen over time, especially if not addressed early.How low Vitamin B12 causes nerve damageVitamin B12 is vital for the production of myelin – the protective coating around nerves. When B12 is deficient, myelin begins to break down, exposing nerves to damage. This can disrupt communication between the brain and the rest of the body, resulting in symptoms like numbness, weakness, and cognitive issues.In severe cases, B12 deficiency can lead to subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, a serious neurological condition that may cause:Stiffness in the limbsPoor coordinationDifficulty walkingLoss of vibration or position senseIf untreated, some of this nerve damage may become permanent.Who is at risk of Vitamin B12 deficiencyVitamin B12 deficiency can affect anyone, but some groups are more vulnerable:Older adults (reduced absorption with age)Vegans and vegetarians (plant foods lack natural B12)People with gastrointestinal conditions, such as Crohn’s disease or coeliac diseaseThose taking certain medications, like metformin or proton pump inhibitorsPatients who have had bariatric or stomach surgeryTreatment options for VitaminB12 deficiency typically includes:Vitamin B12 injections for severe deficiency or poor absorptionOral B12 supplements for mild casesDietary changes to include B12-rich or fortified foodsImprovements may take weeks or months depending on how long the deficiency has been present.When to see a doctorIf you experience symptoms like persistent numbness, tingling, balance issues, or mental fog, speak to your GP. A simple blood test can check your B12 levels. Your doctor may also test homocysteine or methylmalonic acid (MMA) if results are borderline.Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent long-term nerve damage.Frequently Asked QuestionsQ1. Can nerve damage from low B12 be reversed?Yes, but only if caught early. Many symptoms, including fatigue, tingling, and memory issues, often improve with treatment. However, long-term deficiency can lead to irreversible nerve damage, especially in older adults.Q2. Is nerve damage from low vitamin B12 permanent?Nerve damage may be reversible if treated early, but long-term deficiency can cause permanent damage. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential.Also read | Why kidney infections spike during the monsoon season and how to stay safeAbout the AuthorTOI Lifestyle DeskThe TOI Lifestyle Desk is a dynamic team of dedicated journalists who, with unwavering passion and commitment, sift through the pulse of the nation to curate a vibrant tapestry of lifestyle news for The Times of India readers. At the TOI Lifestyle Desk, we go beyond the obvious, delving into the extraordinary. Consider us your lifestyle companion, providing a daily dose of inspiration and information. Basi roti with ghee: 5 reasons to have it for breakfast

Basi roti with ghee: 5 reasons to have it for breakfast Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipfood newsHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipestravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior CareNewslifestylefood-newsBasi roti with ghee: 5 reasons to have it for breakfastTrendingKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesBasi roti with ghee: 5 reasons to have it for breakfastETimes.in /  Aug 11, 2025, 15:00 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeFollow us 1/6Basi roti with ghee: 5 reasons to have it for breakfast    Mornings can get crazy busy, and breakfast is often the meal that gets skipped or rushed. But what you eat first really shapes how your whole day feels, your energy, digestion, and even your mood. That’s where basi roti with ghee quietly shines. It’s basically leftover or slightly fermented whole wheat flatbread, which might not sound exciting, but it’s actually a smart way to cut down on food waste and save a few bucks. In places like UP and Bihar, folks often enjoy it with jaggery, a simple, comforting combo that’s part of everyday life. Add a generous smear of ghee, and it turns into a warm, satisfying breakfast that keeps you going through the busiest mornings. Practical, wholesome, and honestly pretty comforting, it’s a breakfast worth bringing back. Scroll down to discover five simple reasons why basi roti with ghee makes such a great breakfast.”    2/6Basi roti prevents wastage     Let’s be honest, throwing away food just doesn’t sit right with most of us. Basi roti is one of those things that often gets forgotten and tossed, but why waste it? Instead, turn those dry rotis into your new go-to breakfast. It’s an easy way to cut down on waste, save a bit of cash, and still enjoy a warm, comforting meal that actually fills you up. Plus, with everyone talking about being smarter with food these days, basi roti with ghee feels like a small but meaningful way to eat better and live a little kinder.     3/6Gut health gets a delicious boost    Fermented foods have been all the rage for gut health, and basi roti fits right in. That slight fermentation happening in basi roti actually promotes good bacteria in your gut, helping digestion and keeping things running smoothly. Then there’s ghee, which isn’t just tasty – it contains butyrate, a fatty acid known for soothing your digestive tract and reducing inflammation. Together, basi roti and ghee are like a gentle comfort for your gut first thing in the morning.    4/6Steady energy without the crash    If you’re sick of breakfasts that shoot your sugar up and then leave you crashing, basi roti is a total game changer. Since it’s made from whole wheat, it gives you slow, steady energy instead of that quick spike. And when you spread some ghee on top, those good fats help keep you full and focused for way longer. No more sneaking snacks by mid-morning or crashing hard. Just steady energy that stays with you, making it easier to power through your day without any sugar slump.    5/6Filling but easy on your stomach    Nobody wants to feel heavy or slow right after breakfast. Basi roti’s got plenty of fiber from the whole wheat, so it keeps you full without that annoying hunger creeping back too soon. Plus, since it’s a bit fermented, it’s easier on your stomach than fresh bread. Toss on a good spoonful of ghee, and it’s warm, comforting, and just the right amount of filling. It’s the kind of breakfast that just sits right with you and gives you steady energy to power through your morning without feeling wiped out.    6/6Quick and convenient     We all have mornings when time is not on our side. That’s where basi roti shines. Since it’s already made (just leftover from yesterday’s meal), all you need to do is warm it up, add on a generous dollop of ghee, and you’re set. No fancy prep, no complicated recipes. This simple breakfast is perfect for anyone juggling a packed schedule but refusing to sacrifice nutrition.Follow Us On Social Media Visual Stories   PreviousHow to make natural hair colour using tea and coffeeindiaDivyanka Tripathi’s top 10 stylish must-have looksindia​How to make dhaba-style Egg Curry at home​Food9 heart-healthy foods that cut attack and stroke riskindiaSaniya Iyappan steals the spotlight with her graceindiaCarrie Coon’s secret weapon on TV? Swami Premanand Ji Maharaj is a revered spiritual leader known for his deep devotion, inspiring discourses, and guidance on living a virtuous, God-centered life rooted in love and compassion. Here we list some of his quotes on marriages:

Calf muscles and heart health: 3 exercises to do before walking to strengthen these muscles
Calf muscles and heart health: 3 exercises to do before walking to strengthen these muscles
Calf muscles and heart health: 3 exercises to do before walking to strengthen these muscles Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipesfood newstravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior Carehealth newsfitnessdietmental healthcoronavirusalternative therapiesweight lossvideosdiseasesyogaNewslifestylehealth-fitnessCalf muscles and heart health: 3 exercises to do before walking to strengthen these musclesTrendingKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesCalf muscles and heart health: 3 exercises to do before walking to strengthen these musclesETimes.in /  Aug 11, 2025, 13:00 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeFollow us 1/5222/5How do calf muscles help in maintaining heart healthYour heart functions by distributing oxygen-rich blood throughout your arteries to all your organs and tissues. The circulatory process needs blood to return from your feet and legs to your heart through veins, which require working against gravitational forces. The calf muscles function as a crucial system in this process. These muscles function by contracting and relaxing to compress deep leg veins, which pushes blood toward an upward direction. The calf muscle pump function prevents blood from accumulating in your legs, while maintaining normal blood pressure levels. Blood clots and swelling along with heart strain, become more likely when calf muscles are weak or inactive.Enhanced calf muscle strength enables the heart to operate more efficiently while reducing blood pressure, and enhancing overall circulation patterns. Your calf muscles become ready for walking or exercise, when you strengthen them before physical activities, thus minimising the risk of injuries and delivering additional protection to your heart. Here are 3 such exercises...3/5Calf Raises (Heel Raises)Calf raises serve to develop both gastrocnemius and soleus muscles which are primary calf muscle groups.How to do them:Stand with your feet placed hip-width apart while using a wall or chair as support for balance if required.Slowly lift your heels off the floor, rising onto your tiptoes.Maintain this position for one brief moment to feel the calf muscles tightening.Slowly lower your heels back down to the ground.Repeat 15-20 times for 2-3 sets.Why it’s good:Calf raises engage the blood-pumping muscles, which enhance the venous return process. Regular muscle contractions through these exercises, help expand blood vessels and create blood pressure reduction effects. Before starting your walk, these exercises prepare your muscles which then become more powerful, at supporting your cardiovascular system.4/5Seated calf raisesThis exercise targets the soleus muscle, which plays a key role during activities like walking and standing.How to do them:Sit comfortably on a chair with your feet flat on the ground.You should maintain contact between your toes, foot balls, heels and floor, as you elevate your heels to their highest point.Maintain the raised position for one to two seconds, before slowly returning your heels to the floor.Repeat 15-20 times for 2-3 sets.Why it’s good:The exercise of seated calf raises provides a gentle yet effective way to strengthen the muscles, which efficiently pump blood throughout daily activities. The exercise enhances blood flow and minimises leg heaviness and swelling symptoms. This stretch before walking helps protect your heart function during exercise.5/5Calf stretch with wall supportThe practice of calf muscle stretching leads to better flexibility, while improving blood circulation to avoid muscle tightness and injuries.How to do it:Stand an arm’s length away from a wall.Place your hands flat against the wall for support.Take a step backward with one straight foot, while pressing the heel against the floor.Lower your front knee slightly and press against the wall, until you reach the stretch in your calf muscle.Maintain the stretch position for 15 to 20 seconds.Perform this stretch 2 to 3 times on each leg before changing sides.Why it’s good:Stretching allows blood flow to increase, and relaxes the calf muscles before exercise begins. Your ability to walk correctly along with cramp prevention, depends on flexible calf muscles. The stretching process improves blood circulation, which benefits heart health by making blood flow back to your heart more easily.Sources:Aster Hospitals – Calf Muscles and Heart HealthSurrey Physio – 5 Best Ways to Strengthen Your CalvesWebMD – Best Exercises for Strengthening Calf MusclesMoneycontrol – How Calf Muscles Can Keep Cardiovascular Disease at BayDisclaimer: This article is informational only and not a substitute for medical adviceFollow Us On Social Media Visual Stories   PreviousHow to make natural hair colour using tea and coffeeindiaDivyanka Tripathi’s top 10 stylish must-have looksindia​How to make dhaba-style Egg Curry at home​Food9 heart-healthy foods that cut attack and stroke riskindiaSaniya Iyappan steals the spotlight with her graceindiaCarrie Coon’s secret weapon on TV? Milind Soman reveals one daily habit of his mother which helps her stay fit at 86
The physical activity of skipping rope works all major muscle groups starting from your calves and thighs, then moves to your core and finally engages your arms. Your muscles will become stronger while developing better definition, when you jump. The repetitive jumping motion during skipping rope exercises, delivers mild bone-stimulating pressure, which leads to bone growth while reducing osteoporosis risk
Milind Soman reveals one daily habit of his mother which helps her stay fit at 86 | - Times of India Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipesfood newstravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior Carehealth newsfitnessdietmental healthcoronavirusalternative therapiesweight lossvideosdiseasesyogaNewslifestylehealth-fitnessMilind Soman reveals one daily habit of his mother which helps her stay fit at 86TrendingKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesMilind Soman reveals one daily habit of his mother which helps her stay fit at 86TOI Lifestyle Desk / etimes.in / Updated: Aug 11, 2025, 15:37 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeThe physical activity of skipping rope works all major muscle groups starting from your calves and thighs, then moves to your core and finally engages your arms. Your muscles will become stronger while developing better definition, when you jump. The repetitive jumping motion during skipping rope exercises, delivers mild bone-stimulating pressure, which leads to bone growth while reducing osteoporosis risk  Actor and fitness enthusiast Milind Soman, 59 seems to be ageing like fine wine. Whether it is his fit frame, or his awe inspiring fitness videos, the actor goes on to prove that growing older has nothing to do with feeling older. Recently he took to his IG handle to share a family video of himself, his wife Ankita and mom Usha Soman who are all skipping together. Along with the video he revealed that at 86, his Aai (mom) skips everyday for health and fitness. He said, “Family skipping time. Aai (Mother) is now 86, and skipping is something she does every day, apart from yoga and other movements. Long life, health and happiness to all,” Milind wrote in the caption of the post.5 benefits of skipping ropeSkipping rope, though basic, delivers various health advantages to people. Regular rope skipping practices both enhance fitness while delivering benefits to your heart together with your muscles and are also good for your mental health, when combined with other activities. Here's how...Boosts cardiovascular healthThe physical activity of jumping rope is an excellent cardiovascular exercise, which develops both heart and lung strength. Your heart beats faster during rope jumping, which leads to better blood circulation and stronger heart muscles. Research shows that consistent rope skipping practice lowers blood pressure while reducing heart disease risks, through improved lung and heart performance. Your body will function more efficiently, because skipping rope enhances your cardiovascular ability, which supports extended health and active life.Improves coordination and balanceTo jump rope successfully, you need to maintain rhythm while controlling your body movements at precise times. Your brain and muscles work together during skipping, to maintain your balance and coordination. The activity develops your total motor abilities and boosts your agility levels, as well as your reaction speed. Scientific research demonstrates that rope skipping enhances balance, coordination and athletic performance amongst children and athletes. Not only that, the improved coordination helps decrease the chances of falls and daily accidents that lead to injuries. (Research Journal of Pharmacy and Technology – Effect of skipping rope exercise on physical fitness, Elite Jumps Blog – Surprising Benefits of Jumping Rope)Strengthens muscles and bonesThe physical activity of skipping rope works all major muscle groups starting from your calves and thighs, then moves to your core and finally engages your arms. Your muscles will become stronger while developing better definition, when you jump. The repetitive jumping motion during skipping rope exercises, delivers mild bone-stimulating pressure, which leads to bone growth while reducing osteoporosis risk. The regular practice of rope skipping, enhances your leg muscle endurance and maintains bone health, which together create physical strength.Burns calories and aids weight lossThe high-intensity nature of rope skipping makes it an effective workout which burns calories swiftly. You can easily burn 10-15 calories per minute, when you skip rope based on how fast and intensely you jump. This activity works well for weight loss and maintaining proper body weight distribution. Rope skipping engages your entire body, which stimulates metabolic processes while providing daily fitness benefits through brief exercise sessions. (PMC – The effect of an 8-week rope skipping intervention on performance, Cleveland Clinic – 6 Benefits of Jumping Rope)Enhances mental health and reduces stressThe practice of skipping rope delivers dual benefits to both physical health, and mental wellness. Physical exercise boosts endorphin production which creates positive mood effects, while decreasing stress levels. The coordinated movements required for skipping create mental clarity and improved concentration ability. People use rope skipping as a stress relief method, to improve their mental state after working hours.Disclaimer: This article is informational only and not a substitute for medical adviceAbout the AuthorTOI Lifestyle DeskThe TOI Lifestyle Desk is a dynamic team of dedicated journalists who, with unwavering passion and commitment, sift through the pulse of the nation to curate a vibrant tapestry of lifestyle news for The Times of India readers. ​From Banyan to Kadamba: Trees that fulfill wishes
​Certain trees are more than just part of nature; they are living, sacred proof of the divine, carrying stories, blessings, and sacred energy within their roots and flowers. From the wish-granting tree of Kalpavriksha to Shri Krishana’s favourite Kadamba, these unique trees have been revered for centuries. Let us take a look at them one by one​
​From Banyan to Kadamba: Trees that fulfill wishes and grant blessings Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipsoul searchHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artsbeautybooksrecipesfood newstravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior CareNewslifestylesoul-search​From Banyan to Kadamba: Trees that fulfill wishes and grant blessingsTrendingKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest Countries​From Banyan to Kadamba: Trees that fulfill wishes and grant blessingsETimes.in / Updated: Aug 11, 2025, 15:42 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeFollow us 1/5From Banyan to Kadamba: Trees that fulfill wishes and blessingsCertain trees are more than just part of nature; they are living, sacred proof of the divine, carrying stories, blessings, and sacred energy within their roots and flowers. From the wish-granting tree of Kalpavriksha to Shri Krishana’s favourite Kadamba, these unique trees have been revered for centuries. Let us take a look at them one by one2/5Banyan: Tree of lifeThe banyan tree often represents the Trimūrti, the three lords of cosmic creation, preservation, and destruction-namely, Lord Brahma, Lord Vishnu, and Lord Shiva. It is often used for metaphorical reference in the Vedic scriptures written in ancient Sanskrit manuscripts. With its ever-spreading roots and branches, it is also symbolic of life and fertility in the Indian culture and is consequently worshipped by those who wish to have children. The revered banyan tree is never cut, and thus often grows over many acres.3/5Kadamba treeCommon Bur Flower or Kadam (Neolamarckia Cadamba) is a large, evergreen tree with beautiful & unique flowers. It is a fast-growing tree with a broad crown and is even planted sacredly near temples. In Hindu mythology, the Kadam tree is the favourite tree of Lord Krishna, who is usually depicted playing his flute under it. He also used to play with his friends under the Kadam tree in Vrindavan, using the unique globular flower of the tree. Hence, the tree is also known as Haripriya, God's favourite.4/5Bael: The medicinal plantThe bael is a slender, aromatic tree that bears a sweet, yellow-green fruit. It is a medicinal plant as well as a sacred tree. All parts of it are used for different healing purposes-the roots, leaves, and fruits-and it has proven effective in combating many different kinds of bacteria. It is known as “Sivadruma”, and the leaves are often offered to Lord Shiva, who is known to be particularly pleased by this tree. Baels have trifoliate leaves, i.e., a leaf structure of three, and this is sometimes thought to symbolize Siva’s trident or the Trimūrti, Brahma, Vishnu, and Mahesh.5/5Peepal: Tree of enlightenmentThis tree, also known as “Ashvatta,” is purportedly the most worshipped tree in India. Lord Krishna, the original incarnation of Lord Vishnu and the supreme lord of the universe according to the legends, identifies with the peepul in the sacred text Bhagavad Gita. He states, “Of all trees, I am the holy fig tree (Bhagavad Gita Verse 10.26).” In addition, the Hindus associate the roots of the tree with Lord Brahma (the creator of the universe), the trunk of the tree with Lord Vishnu (the protector and preserver), and the leaves of the tree with Lord Shiva (the destroyer).Follow Us On Social Media Visual Stories   Previous10 animals that can survive intense radiationLifestyle10 Indian states with maximum number of National ParkstravelHow to make natural hair colour using tea and coffeeLifestyleDivyanka Tripathi’s top 10 stylish must-have lookstv​How to make dhaba-style Egg Curry at home​Food9 heart-healthy foods that cut attack and stroke riskLifestyleSaniya Iyappan steals the spotlight with her graceEntertainmentCarrie Coon’s secret weapon on TV?
