Your heart sends warnings 12 years before a heart attack; here’s the sign most people miss and preventions steps you need to know now
Research reveals physical activity often decreases years before heart issues arise. A study shows moderate exercise declines about 12 years before diagnosis. This decline accelerates in the final two years. Doctors like Dr. Sudhir Kumar advise recognizing early stamina loss. Early detection allows for timely prevention and lifestyle changes. These interventions can prevent major cardiac events.
Your heart sends warnings 12 years before a heart attack; here’s the sign most people miss and preventions steps you need to know now | - Times of India Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipesfood newstravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior Carehealth newsfitnessdietmental healthcoronavirusalternative therapiesweight lossvideosdiseasesyogaNewslifestylehealth-fitnesshealth-newsYour heart sends warnings 12 years before a heart attack; here’s the sign most people miss and preventions steps you need to know nowTrendingKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesYour heart sends warnings 12 years before a heart attack; here’s the sign most people miss and preventions steps you need to know nowTOI Lifestyle Desk / etimes.in /  Aug 11, 2025, 15:02 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeResearch reveals physical activity often decreases years before heart issues arise. A study shows moderate exercise declines about 12 years before diagnosis. This decline accelerates in the final two years. Doctors like Dr. Sudhir Kumar advise recognizing early stamina loss. Early detection allows for timely prevention and lifestyle changes. These interventions can prevent major cardiac events.  Heart attacks are usually framed as sudden emergencies, but research shows they commonly follow a slow, silent buildup that begins long before pain or hospital alarms. A major analysis of CARDIA participants found that moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) — things like brisk walking, cycling or swimming — often starts a steady decline about 12 years before a cardiovascular diagnosis, with the pace accelerating in the final two years. Experts including Dr. Sudhir Kumar (Apollo Hospitals, Hyderabad) warn that this gradual loss of stamina is frequently misread as normal ageing; spotting it early creates a large window for prevention, screening and targeted lifestyle or medical interventions that can avert major cardiac events. Physical activity often starts falling 12 years before heart disease: StudyThe paper titled “Trajectories of Physical Activity Before and After Cardiovascular Disease Events in CARDIA Participants” analysed physical activity data collected across decades from participants first enrolled in 1985–86. Researchers used repeated activity assessments (multiple timepoints through midlife) to model long-term trajectories and compare people who later developed cardiovascular disease (CVD) with those who did not.The key quantitative findings: MVPA began to decline, on average, roughly 12 years before a first CVD event; declines steeped in the two years immediately before diagnosis; and low activity levels tended to persist after the event, widening the gap versus peers who remained CVD-free. The study used CARDIA’s longitudinal design to reveal this long preclinical window rather than a single cross-sectional snapshot. CARDIA tracked moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) — activities that raise heart rate and breathing noticeably (brisk walking, jogging, cycling, swimming, sports). In practice, MVPA estimates came from validated activity questionnaires administered repeatedly; these give a life-course view rather than a one-off reading. Because changes emerged gradually over a decade, the timing matters: a single clinic visit that notes “low activity today” can miss whether someone is on a downward trajectory. Longitudinal decline, especially an accelerating fall in MVPA is the important signal researchers flagged. Changes that raise heart disease riskA sustained drop in MVPA is not just a lifestyle statistic; it maps to several physiologic changes that raise cardiovascular risk:Cardiac deconditioning: Less habitual activity reduces cardiac stroke volume and aerobic capacity, so daily exertion becomes harder.Endothelial and vascular changes: Lack of movement promotes poorer endothelial function and favours atherogenic plaque formation.Metabolic effects: Inactivity increases the risk of weight gain, insulin resistance and adverse lipid changes — all major drivers of atherosclerosis.Inflammation and autonomic imbalance: Sedentary behaviour links to low-grade inflammation and less favourable autonomic (heart rate variability) profiles.Together, these pathways mean a progressive drop in MVPA both reflects and contributes to the biological processes that eventually cause heart attacks or strokes. For public guidance, major health bodies emphasise staying active because of these mechanistic links. MVPA declines over time reflect race and gender inequalities in heart healthCARDIA authors also examined demographic patterns. While MVPA tended to decline across all groups with age, the trajectory and baseline levels differed by sex and race. Notably, the study found that Black women recorded consistently lower activity levels across adulthood, and certain groups showed more continuous declines — patterns that can concentrate cardiovascular risk in already disadvantaged populations. These findings imply prevention must be tailored: population-level recommendations are necessary but insufficient without culturally and structurally appropriate supports. Think longitudinally, not just cross-sectionally. A single “low activity” datapoint is less informative than a trend; clinicians should ask about changes in routine and stamina over years.Use risk tools alongside functional history. Tools such as the ASCVD Risk Estimator help assess 10-year risk, but trend information about MVPA can flag patients who might benefit from earlier screening or intervention. Act early. Declining MVPA constitutes a window for action — lifestyle counselling, targeted exercise support, and if indicated, medical risk-factor treatment (BP, lipids, glycemia). The earlier the intervention, the greater the chance of preventing an event. How to evaluate a patient’s steady decline in staminaIf a patient reports a steady, unexplained fall in activity or stamina, reasonable initial steps include:Basic cardiovascular screening: blood pressure, BMI/waist measure, lipid panel, fasting glucose/HbA1c. Calculate ASCVD or other validated risk scores (for patients in the appropriate age range) to guide intensity of preventive therapy. Functional assessment: a simple timed walk or effort-tolerance discussion can be very revealing; refer for formal stress testing only if clinical suspicion of ischemia is present. Consider social drivers: ask about work, caregiving, safety, access to safe walking spaces and time pressures — these often explain activity declines and must be addressed.From prevention to recovery: Practical guidelines for safe and sustainable cardiovascular fitnessPublic health and cardiology bodies recommend at least 150 minutes per week of moderate-intensity activity (or 75 minutes of vigorous activity) as a baseline goal for adults; more gives additional benefit. Practical tips to meet and sustain MVPA:Break activity into short, consistent bouts (eg. , 30 minutes, 5 days/week).Choose enjoyable activities (walking, cycling, swimming, dance) to improve adherence.Build movement into routines (active commuting, stairs, standing breaks at work).Set trajectory goals rather than single-day targets (track weekly MVPA minutes).Address barriers (childcare, unsafe neighbourhoods, pain) with tailored solutions or supervised programs. If someone does have a cardiovascular event, the evidence strongly supports early referral to structured cardiac rehabilitation (CR). CR combines monitored exercise, risk-factor management, nutrition and psychosocial support; it reduces mortality and improves functional recovery. Typical guidance: begin activity gently (short walks) in hospital recovery, progress under supervision to 30+ minutes of aerobic activity several times weekly, and incorporate supervised outpatient CR when available.How to track activity trends (tools that help detect a worrying decline)Wearables and phone apps: track MVPA minutes and weekly totals. Look for a sustained downward slope over months/years, not day-to-day noise.Simple logs: a weekly activity diary or 6-minute walk distance recorded every few months provides a low-tech trend.Clinical prompts: clinicians should routinely ask, “Compared with two years ago, do you find doing your usual activities harder?” A “yes” can prompt further evaluation.Also Read | Boost liver function with this gut-friendly no-bake date bar supporting overall wellness; gastroenterologist shares easy homemade recipeAbout the AuthorTOI Lifestyle DeskThe TOI Lifestyle Desk is a dynamic team of dedicated journalists who, with unwavering passion and commitment, sift through the pulse of the nation to curate a vibrant tapestry of lifestyle news for The Times of India readers. At the TOI Lifestyle Desk, we go beyond the obvious, delving into the extraordinary. Consider us your lifestyle companion, providing a daily dose of inspiration and information. Meghan Markle burst into tears over Prince William's cruel bullying statement
Meghan Markle was reportedly distraught after Buckingham Palace released a statement denying Prince William bullied her and Prince Harry, a claim made without Harry's consent. Harry felt betrayed, believing the Palace prioritized William's reputation over protecting them from misinformation.
‘No one asked my permission’:  Meghan Markle burst into tears over Prince William's cruel bullying statement - Times of India Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipesfood newstravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior Carelove & sexworkpetssoul curryask the expertvideosNewslifestylerelationshipslove-sex‘No one asked my permission’:  Meghan Markle burst into tears over Prince William's cruel bullying statement‘No one asked my permission’:  Meghan Markle burst into tears over Prince William's cruel bullying statementTOI Lifestyle Desk / etimes.in /  Aug 11, 2025, 13:20 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeMeghan Markle was reportedly distraught after Buckingham Palace released a statement denying Prince William bullied her and Prince Harry, a claim made without Harry's consent. Harry felt betrayed, believing the Palace prioritized William's reputation over protecting them from misinformation. Prince Harry and Meghan Markle/@Instagram Meghan Markle was left visibly shaken following the release of a statement by Buckingham Palace refuting allegations that Prince William bullied her and Prince Harry out of their royal duties. The couple has stated that the action came as a shock to them since it was released without Harry's consent and, in their opinion, did not depict their side of the story.The moment that sparked the debateIn the Netflix documentary Harry & Meghan, Harry recalled the moment he saw the statement and realised it had gone out without his consent. “No one had asked me for permission,” he said. When he told Meghan, she broke down. “She burst into floods of tears,” he added.The statement was issued by Buckingham Palace on behalf of both princes in January 2020, but according to Prince Harry in the Harry & Meghan documentary, he never agreed to it or even knew it was going out.The claim was intended to counter rumors that suggested William's conduct was a reason why the Duchess of Sussex had decided to step back from public life. Media speculations at the time were circulating over tensions in the palace. Harry believed that the palace was set to protect William's reputation, but failed to provide the same level of haste to defend him and Meghan from the spread of misinformation.For three years, they were never going to tell the truth to protect us," Harry said. "But within four hours, they were willing to lie to protect my brother." His words reflected the profound sense of betrayal he and Meghan felt afterwards.The episode is now routinely cited as among the pivotal moments that pushed the brothers further apart. Once close and united in their bereavement over their mother, Princess Diana, the princes have drifted apart. William continues to serve in his position in the UK, while Harry and Meghan have established a new life with their kids, Archie and Lilibet, in California.Signals of a possible rowCredit: InstagramNevertheless, there have been subtle hints that the chill in the air between the Sussexes and the remaining royal members may be dissipating. Rumors indicate a low-key encounter occurred in London amongst Harry's top PR communications adviser, Liam Maguire, his US counterpart, Meredith Maines, and King Charles's senior media aide, Tobyn Andreae. The encounter, held social style with drinks, allegedly was agenda-free. Instead, it gave a chance for honest dialogue, something that some insiders perceive as a good beginning.One insider characterized the meeting as a welcome moment of positive discussion after decades of tension. "There's a long road ahead, but a channel of communication is now open for the first time in years," the insider said. For Harry and Meghan, the recollection of being exposed and left vulnerable as a story they contest took hold is not likely to be forgotten soon.Whether or not this new avenue of communication will amount to genuine reconciliation is far from clear. The family's public and private spheres are so closely linked that rebuilding personal relationships tends to involve negotiating public opinion as well. At times like these, each word, each appearance, and each perceived silence can have enduring repercussions.The road aheadFor the time being, the controversy over the controversial comment remains a chilling reminder of the difficulties experienced by the Sussexes during their service as senior royals. It shows how disagreements in style and priorities within the royal family can have a profound emotional consequence, particularly when trust has been breached.If reconciliation is to happen, it will be more than a matter of one meeting. It will involve time, continued discussion, and a commitment from all parties to admit past resentments without allowing them to dictate the future.About the AuthorTOI Lifestyle DeskThe TOI Lifestyle Desk is a dynamic team of dedicated journalists who, with unwavering passion and commitment, sift through the pulse of the nation to curate a vibrant tapestry of lifestyle news for The Times of India readers. At the TOI Lifestyle Desk, we go beyond the obvious, delving into the extraordinary. Consider us your lifestyle companion, providing a daily dose of inspiration and information. How middle-class families can save INR 1.2 crore in 10 years, CA shares
CA Nitin Kaushik suggests that middle-class Indian families can accumulate INR 1.2 crores in 10 years through disciplined financial planning. His strategy involves early investment in SIPs and PPF for children, patient home buying with substantial down payments, and boosting retirement savings beyond EPF. Kaushik emphasizes consistent saving habits, avoiding lifestyle inflation, and tracking expenses to achieve financial goals.
How Indian middle-class families can build over INR 1.2 crore in just 10 years, without a big salary-- CA shares tips - Times of India Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipesfood newstravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior Carelove & sexworkpetssoul curryask the expertvideosNewslifestylerelationshipsHow Indian middle-class families can build over INR 1.2 crore in just 10 years, without a big salary-- CA shares tipsTrendingKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesHow Indian middle-class families can build over INR 1.2 crore in just 10 years, without a big salary-- CA shares tipsTOI Lifestyle Desk / etimes.in /  Aug 11, 2025, 14:15 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeCA Nitin Kaushik suggests that middle-class Indian families can accumulate INR 1.2 crores in 10 years through disciplined financial planning. His strategy involves early investment in SIPs and PPF for children, patient home buying with substantial down payments, and boosting retirement savings beyond EPF. Kaushik emphasizes consistent saving habits, avoiding lifestyle inflation, and tracking expenses to achieve financial goals.  For many middle-class Indian families, having a home of their own, enough funds to send kids to study abroad, savings of over INR 1.2 crores, and to retire with financial stability sounds like a dream. With modest incomes, rising costs of living, and unexpected expenses, saving big often feels impossible for many. But Chartered Accountant (CA) Nitin Kaushik believes otherwise.In a detailed post on X (formerly known as Twitter), CA Nitin Kaushik explained that with discipline, smart planning, and consistent investing habits, even people with average incomes can build a wealth of INR 1.2 crores in just 10 years. Here's how, as per Kaushik's post on X:1. Start financial planning earlyOne of Kaushik’s biggest tips is to set priorities from the start. For parents, this means beginning a child’s investment plan right from their birth. By investing just INR 10,000 per month — split between Systematic Investment Plans (SIPs) in index funds and the Public Provident Fund (PPF) — parents can target to save upto INR 60 lakh in 15 years.The math works out through the power of compounding: Mutual funds can potentially earn about 12% annually, while PPF offers safety, tax benefits, and stable returns. Occasional top-ups boost the total even more.2. Buy a home without breaking your financesFor most Indians, owning a home is a major dream— but Kaushik advises people to be patient with it. Instead of jumping into a long-term home loan, families can initially rent while saving aggressively on the side. Aim to have at least 25% of the property price as a down payment before buying.When taking a loan, keep the tenure short (10 years instead of 20) and ensure EMIs don’t exceed 35% of your monthly income. This approach reduces interest costs, speeds up loan repayment, and leaves room for other investments.3. Start saving for your retirement nowRelying only on the Employees’ Provident Fund (EPF) is risky. Kaushik suggests gradually increasing contributions to the National Pension System (NPS) and running separate retirement-focused SIPs. The goal: build INR 30–35 lakh in retirement savings within 10 years. This diversified plan provides a safety net against inflation and unforeseen expenses.4. Small habits make big impactWealth is not just about how much you earn, but how consistently you save. Kaushik recommends:- Avoid lifestyle inflation (don’t let expenses grow just because your income does)- Track your spending with a simple spreadsheet- Delay going on expensive vacations until your savings goals are met- Celebrate milestones like hitting ₹5 lakh in SIP investments or prepaying loansThe 10-year outcomeBy following this plan, Kaushik says a typical family could achieve:INR 72 lakh from mutual fundsINR 28 lakh from PPF, EPF, and NPSINR 8 lakh in fixed deposits and emergency fundsINR 15 lakh in home equity (after loan adjustments)Even after accounting for liabilities such as a INR 22 lakh home loan balance, the net worth exceeds INR 1.2 crore in 10 years.Kaushik’s message is simple: Wealth is built slowly — through patience, consistent investing, and smart financial decisions — not by chasing quick profits. For middle-class families, starting early and staying disciplined can turn modest salaries into a strong financial future.About the AuthorTOI Lifestyle DeskThe TOI Lifestyle Desk is a dynamic team of dedicated journalists who, with unwavering passion and commitment, sift through the pulse of the nation to curate a vibrant tapestry of lifestyle news for The Times of India readers. At the TOI Lifestyle Desk, we go beyond the obvious, delving into the extraordinary. Consider us your lifestyle companion, providing a daily dose of inspiration and information. Whether you're seeking the latest fashion trends, travel escapades, culinary delights, or wellness tips, the TOI Lifestyle Desk is your one-stop destination for an enriching lifestyle experience.Read MoreEnd of ArticleFollow Us On Social Media Visual Stories   PreviousHow to make natural hair colour using tea and coffeeLifestyleDivyanka Tripathi’s top 10 stylish must-have lookstv9 heart-healthy foods that cut attack and stroke riskLifestyleSaniya Iyappan steals the spotlight with her graceEntertainmentCarrie Coon’s secret weapon on TV? 8 benefits of hazelnuts: Improve heart health, boost brain power and enhance skin glow
Hazelnuts, a nutrient-rich superfood, offer a multitude of health benefits. Packed with antioxidants, healthy fats, and essential nutrients, they support heart health, boost brain function, and promote healthy digestion. Incorporating a moderate amount of hazelnuts into your daily diet can enhance overall well-being, contributing to stronger bones, glowing skin, and reduced inflammation.
8 benefits of hazelnuts: Improve heart health, boost brain power and enhance skin glow | - Times of India Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipfood newsHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipestravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior CareNewslifestylefood-news8 benefits of hazelnuts: Improve heart health, boost brain power and enhance skin glowTrendingKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest Countries8 benefits of hazelnuts: Improve heart health, boost brain power and enhance skin glowTOI Lifestyle Desk / etimes.in / Updated: Aug 11, 2025, 15:21 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeHazelnuts, a nutrient-rich superfood, offer a multitude of health benefits. Packed with antioxidants, healthy fats, and essential nutrients, they support heart health, boost brain function, and promote healthy digestion. Incorporating a moderate amount of hazelnuts into your daily diet can enhance overall well-being, contributing to stronger bones, glowing skin, and reduced inflammation.  Hazelnuts, also called filberts, are more than just a crunchy snack or a sweet ingredient in chocolate spreads. These nutrient-rich nuts are loaded with vitamins, minerals, healthy fats, and powerful antioxidants that make them a true superfood. From protecting your heart and boosting brain function to improving skin glow and supporting digestion, hazelnuts can benefit almost every part of your body. They are also a natural source of protein, fibre, and essential fatty acids, making them an excellent choice for those seeking a balanced and wholesome diet. Whether eaten raw, roasted, or blended into nut butter, adding a handful of hazelnuts to your daily routine can be a delicious way to improve your health and well-being.8 health benefits of hazelnuts to improve your over all health Hazelnuts are packed with antioxidantsStudies published in NIH have confirmed that hazelnuts are rich in vitamin E, manganese, and phenolic compounds, which act as powerful antioxidants. These help protect your cells from oxidative stress, slowing the ageing process and reducing the risk of chronic diseases such as cancer and heart disease.Surprisingly easy ways to protect your brain and prevent strokeSupport heart health and manage cholesterolStudies in NIH show hazelnuts promote better cholesterol balance by lowering LDL (bad) cholesterol and increasing HDL (good) cholesterol. High in monounsaturated fats and dietary fibre, this combination supports blood vessel flexibility, improves circulation, and reduces the risk of cardiovascular issues.Help regulate blood sugar levelsResearch by NIH confirms that the low glycaemic index of hazelnuts, combined with their magnesium content, supports blood sugar stability. Regular consumption can help those managing type 2 diabetes and may lower the risk of developing insulin resistance.Promote healthy digestionA small handful of hazelnuts provides enough dietary fibre to aid digestion, prevent constipation, and promote healthy gut bacteria. Good digestive health also supports nutrient absorption, ensuring your body makes the most of your meals.Boost brain health and cognitive functionHazelnuts provide essential nutrients for brain performance, including vitamin E, manganese, thiamine, and healthy fats. These nutrients protect brain cells, improve memory, and support sharper mental focus as you age.Enhance skin and hair healthVitamin E and healthy fats in hazelnuts nourish skin cells, helping maintain hydration and elasticity. They also protect against sun damage and oxidative stress. The same nutrients contribute to stronger, shinier hair.Reduce inflammation naturallyResearch by NIH shows that hazelnuts have anti-inflammatory compounds that may reduce chronic inflammation, a root cause of many serious conditions like heart disease, arthritis, and certain cancers.Strengthen bonesWith magnesium, calcium, and phosphorus, hazelnuts support bone density and strength. This makes them a valuable food for preventing osteoporosis and maintaining mobility as you age.How to Enjoy Hazelnuts SafelyHazelnuts may be a nutritional powerhouse, but like most nuts, they are calorie-dense, meaning it’s easy to overeat them without realising. To enjoy their health benefits without consuming excess calories, aim for a serving of 20–30 grams per day roughly a small handful. This amount is enough to provide essential vitamins, minerals, healthy fats, and antioxidants without significantly affecting your daily calorie balance.If you have a nut allergy, it’s best to avoid hazelnuts completely, as even small traces can trigger reactions. For everyone else, there are plenty of delicious ways to include them in your diet. You can eat them raw for maximum nutrient retention, roast them for a deeper flavour, sprinkle chopped hazelnuts over salads or yoghurt, blend them into smoothies for a creamy texture, or enjoy them as a natural hazelnut butter. Pairing hazelnuts with fresh fruit, dark chocolate, or whole grains can also create tasty, balanced snacks that keep you full for longer.From heart health and brain support to glowing skin, better digestion, and stronger bones, hazelnuts are a versatile superfood worth adding to your diet. Just remember, moderation is key. Enjoy them regularly as part of a balanced diet, and their benefits will reward you for years to come.Also read| 10 benefits of karela juice daily: Boost immunity, manage blood sugar, support digestionAbout the AuthorTOI Lifestyle DeskThe TOI Lifestyle Desk is a dynamic team of dedicated journalists who, with unwavering passion and commitment, sift through the pulse of the nation to curate a vibrant tapestry of lifestyle news for The Times of India readers. At the TOI Lifestyle Desk, we go beyond the obvious, delving into the extraordinary. Consider us your lifestyle companion, providing a daily dose of inspiration and information. Whether you're seeking the latest fashion trends, travel escapades, culinary delights, or wellness tips, the TOI Lifestyle Desk is your one-stop destination for an enriching lifestyle experience.Read MoreEnd of ArticleFollow Us On Social Media Visual Stories   Previous10 animals that can survive intense radiationLifestyleHow to make natural hair colour using tea and coffeeLifestyleDivyanka Tripathi’s top 10 stylish must-have lookstv9 heart-healthy foods that cut attack and stroke riskLifestyleSaniya Iyappan steals the spotlight with her graceEntertainmentCarrie Coon’s secret weapon on TV? 10 benefits of drinking karela juice daily: Boost immunity, manage blood sugar, support digestion
Karela juice, a traditional remedy derived from bitter gourd, offers a range of health benefits. Rich in vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants, it boosts immunity, aids digestion, and supports weight loss. Studies suggest it helps regulate blood sugar, detoxifies the liver, enhances skin health, and may possess anti-cancer properties. While beneficial, moderation is key to avoid potential side effects.
10 benefits of drinking karela juice daily: Boost immunity, manage blood sugar, support digestion | - Times of India Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipfood newsHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipestravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior CareNewslifestylefood-news10 benefits of drinking karela juice daily: Boost immunity, manage blood sugar, support digestionTrendingKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest Countries10 benefits of drinking karela juice daily: Boost immunity, manage blood sugar, support digestionTOI Lifestyle Desk / etimes.in /  Aug 11, 2025, 13:30 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeKarela juice, a traditional remedy derived from bitter gourd, offers a range of health benefits. Rich in vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants, it boosts immunity, aids digestion, and supports weight loss. Studies suggest it helps regulate blood sugar, detoxifies the liver, enhances skin health, and may possess anti-cancer properties. While beneficial, moderation is key to avoid potential side effects.   Karela juice, made from the humble bitter gourd, is one of those age-old remedies that has stood the test of time. Its sharp, bitter taste might make you wince, but behind that strong flavour lies a treasure chest of health benefits. For centuries, karela has been used in Ayurveda and traditional Chinese medicine to treat a variety of ailments, from digestive troubles to blood sugar imbalances. Today, modern nutrition science is catching up, recognising karela juice as a functional health drink rich in vitamins, minerals, fibre, and powerful plant compounds.When consumed regularly (in moderation), karela juice can help improve immunity, support healthy digestion, promote weight loss, and even enhance skin health. Whether you’re looking to manage blood sugar naturally or simply want a nutrient-packed drink to start your morning, karela juice can be a game-changer in your daily wellness routine. Let’s explore its top 10 health benefits.10 health benefits of drinking karela juice every dayBoosts immunity with vitamin c and zincAccording to a study in BMC, karela juice is a natural immune system ally. High in vitamin C, zinc, and flavonoids, it helps your body fight off infections more effectively. The antioxidants in karela juice neutralise free radicals, lowering inflammation and helping your body recover faster from illnesses. A regular intake can be particularly beneficial during seasonal changes when colds and flu are more common.Improves digestion and relieves bloatingBitter foods have long been valued for their ability to stimulate digestion, and karela juice is no exception. Its fibre content aids bowel regularity, while digestive enzymes in the juice encourage the breakdown of food for easier absorption. If you often experience bloating, gas, or indigestion, a small serving of karela juice before meals can help ease discomfort and improve nutrient uptake.Supports weight loss naturallyIf you’re aiming to lose weight without extreme diets, karela juice can be a supportive addition. It’s low in calories but rich in dietary fibre, which keeps you full for longer and curbs unnecessary snacking. Certain compounds in karela also help regulate blood sugar, preventing sudden spikes and crashes that often lead to sugar cravings. When paired with a balanced diet and regular exercise, it can accelerate fat loss in a healthy way.Helps regulate blood sugar levelsPerhaps the most famous benefit of karela juice is its role in blood sugar management. Studies by NIH confirmed that it contains compounds like charantin, vicine, and polypeptide-P — all of which mimic the effects of insulin, helping glucose enter cells more efficiently. This makes it a natural aid for people looking to keep their blood sugar within healthy ranges. However, if you’re on diabetes medication, consult your doctor before adding karela juice to your diet to avoid hypoglycemia.Protects cells from damage with antioxidantsOxidative stress is linked to premature ageing and chronic diseases, but karela juice’s antioxidant profile can help counter it. According to NIH’s studies, vitamins A and C, along with polyphenols, work together to protect cells from damage, maintain healthy tissues, and support overall vitality. Regular consumption may also reduce the risk of certain inflammatory conditions.Promotes liver detox and gut healthYour liver plays a key role in detoxification, and karela juice supports this vital process. It stimulates bile production, which aids fat digestion and helps the body eliminate toxins. A well-functioning liver not only supports digestion but also improves metabolism and overall energy levels.Enhances skin health and fights acneThe skin-clearing benefits of karela juice come from its detoxifying and anti-inflammatory properties. By flushing out toxins from the bloodstream, it reduces skin irritation, redness, and breakouts. It’s also rich in vitamin C, which supports collagen production, keeping skin firm and youthful. Regular drinkers often notice a brighter complexion over time.Shows potential anti-cancer propertiesEmerging research by NIH suggests that karela extract may have compounds that slow down the growth of certain cancer cells, particularly in the colon, liver, and breast. While karela juice is not a cure, its high antioxidant content and ability to support immune health may play a protective role when combined with a nutrient-rich diet.Provides antimicrobial and antiviral benefitsKarela juice contains bioactive compounds with antibacterial and antiviral effects, helping to protect against infections. Traditionally, it has been used to fight intestinal worms and improve gut microbial balance. In modern times, this property adds to its role in supporting immunity.Aids wound healing in diabeticsSome studies by NIH show that karela juice can promote wound healing, especially in people with diabetes. By improving blood circulation and reducing inflammation, it supports tissue repair and recovery. However, this should be used as a complementary remedy, not a replacement for medical treatment.Karela juice is a powerful natural remedy, but like all good things, it should be consumed in moderation. Its benefits range from strengthening immunity and aiding weight loss to improving skin health and supporting digestion. However, overconsumption may cause digestive discomfort, diarrhoea, or dangerously low blood sugar levels, especially for those on diabetic medication. Pregnant and breastfeeding women should avoid it without medical advice. For safe consumption, start with 30–50 ml diluted in water a few times a week and gradually increase if needed. Its bitter flavour may take time to get used to, but when enjoyed regularly and in moderation, karela juice can be a valuable addition to a balanced, healthy lifestyle.Also read| 7 best green teas to support weight management and overall healthAbout the AuthorTOI Lifestyle DeskThe TOI Lifestyle Desk is a dynamic team of dedicated journalists who, with unwavering passion and commitment, sift through the pulse of the nation to curate a vibrant tapestry of lifestyle news for The Times of India readers. 5 simple daily habits to improve your sleep quality naturally
Millions struggle with sleep quality, impacting health and energy. Experts recommend simple lifestyle tweaks for better rest. These include changing pillow covers weekly, avoiding evening caffeine and heavy late meals, limiting screen time, and maintaining a consistent bedtime routine. These adjustments promote relaxation, boost melatonin, and support the body's natural sleep-wake cycle.
5 simple daily habits to improve your sleep quality naturally | - Times of India Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipesfood newstravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior Carehealth newsfitnessdietmental healthcoronavirusalternative therapiesweight lossvideosdiseasesyogaNewslifestylehealth-fitnesshealth-news5 simple daily habits to improve your sleep quality naturallyTrendingKidney DamageColon CancerVitamin B12 DeficiencyKidney DiseaseBeautiful Aquarium FishesFatty LiverTamannaah BhatiaOptical IllusionEgg Cooking MethodsYellow BirdsKidney DamageColon CancerVitamin B12 DeficiencyKidney DiseaseBeautiful Aquarium FishesFatty LiverTamannaah BhatiaOptical IllusionEgg Cooking MethodsYellow BirdsKidney DamageColon CancerVitamin B12 DeficiencyKidney DiseaseBeautiful Aquarium FishesFatty LiverTamannaah BhatiaOptical IllusionEgg Cooking MethodsYellow Birds5 simple daily habits to improve your sleep quality naturallyTOI Lifestyle Desk / etimes.in /  Aug 11, 2025, 11:45 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeMillions struggle with sleep quality, impacting health and energy. Experts recommend simple lifestyle tweaks for better rest. These include changing pillow covers weekly, avoiding evening caffeine and heavy late meals, limiting screen time, and maintaining a consistent bedtime routine. These adjustments promote relaxation, boost melatonin, and support the body's natural sleep-wake cycle.  Good sleep isn’t a luxury, it’s a vital part of maintaining physical health, emotional balance, and mental clarity. Yet, millions of people struggle with falling asleep, staying asleep, or waking up refreshed. The problem isn’t always the number of hours you spend in bed, but the quality of those hours. Sleep experts highlight that small daily habits, like when you drink your coffee or how often you change your pillow cover, can have a surprisingly big impact on how well you rest. By making a few simple changes, you can improve your sleep quality, enhance your energy levels during the day, and even boost your overall immunity. Here are five expert-recommended lifestyle tweaks that can help you sleep better, starting tonight.5 habits to change for a restful night’s sleep naturallyChange your pillow cover regularly for better sleep qualityAccording to a study published in sleep foundation, clean pillow cover supports both hygiene and restful sleep. Over time, pillowcases collect dust mites, allergens, skin oils, and sweat, all of which can trigger discomfort, respiratory irritation, or even mild allergic reactions. These irritations may cause restless nights or frequent wake-ups. Washing or replacing your pillow cover at least once a week creates a fresher, healthier sleep environment, helping your body relax more easily into deep, restorative rest.Avoid evening caffeine to improve sleep qualityStudies done by sleep foundation have shown that caffeine is a stimulant that can stay in your system for up to eight hours. Even a late-afternoon coffee, tea, or energy drink can delay sleep onset and reduce deep sleep stages. For better sleep, cut off caffeine at least six hours before bedtime. Switch to herbal teas, warm milk, or simply water in the evenings to allow your nervous system to wind down naturally.Skip heavy meals before bed for better digestion and sleepEating heavy, rich, or spicy meals late at night forces your body to focus on digestion instead of relaxation. This can cause indigestion, bloating, or acid reflux, all of which disturb sleep quality. To improve both digestion and sleep, try finishing dinner at least two to three hours before bedtime. If you feel hungry later, opt for a light snack like a banana or a handful of nuts.Limit screen time to boost sleep qualityResearch by sleep foundation has confirmed that exposure to blue light from phones, TVs, and laptops suppresses melatonin production, the hormone that signals your body it’s time to sleep. By scrolling in bed or watching late-night shows, you’re telling your brain to stay alert. For better sleep, switch off all screens at least an hour before bedtime. Instead, choose activities like reading a book, meditating, or gentle stretching to help your body prepare for rest.Follow a consistent bedtime routine for long-term sleep improvementYour body’s internal clock, or circadian rhythm, thrives on consistency. Going to bed and waking up at the same time each day reinforces your natural sleep-wake cycle, making it easier to fall asleep and wake up without feeling groggy. Include calming rituals like a warm shower, soft music, or journaling in your nightly routine to signal your body that it’s time to wind down.Quick recap table for sleep improvementHabitChange to makeHow it helps sleep qualityPillow hygieneWash/replace weeklyReduces allergens and discomfortEvening caffeineAvoid after afternoonHelps you fall asleep fasterHeavy late mealsEat 2–3 hours before bedPrevents digestive discomfortScreen exposureStop 1 hour before bedBoosts melatonin productionIrregular sleep scheduleKeep consistent routineSupports circadian rhythmImproving your sleep quality doesn’t always require medical intervention or drastic lifestyle changes. By making these five adjustments, keeping your bedding fresh, skipping evening caffeine, avoiding late heavy meals, limiting screen time, and committing to a consistent bedtime routine, you give your body the right environment for deep, restorative rest. Try implementing one change at a time, and you may find yourself not only sleeping better but also feeling more energized, focused, and balanced during the day.Also read| Why you shouldn’t shower right after eating: Lifestyle coach reveals the impact on digestionAbout the AuthorTOI Lifestyle DeskThe TOI Lifestyle Desk is a dynamic team of dedicated journalists who, with unwavering passion and commitment, sift through the pulse of the nation to curate a vibrant tapestry of lifestyle news for The Times of India readers. At the TOI Lifestyle Desk, we go beyond the obvious, delving into the extraordinary. Consider us your lifestyle companion, providing a daily dose of inspiration and information. Whether you're seeking the latest fashion trends, travel escapades, culinary delights, or wellness tips, the TOI Lifestyle Desk is your one-stop destination for an enriching lifestyle experience.Read MoreEnd of ArticleFollow Us On Social Media Visual Stories   PreviousSaniya Iyappan steals the spotlight with her graceEntertainmentCarrie Coon’s secret weapon on TV? Who is Keonho? Meet HYBE’s stunning new CORTIS member
Who is Keonho? Meet HYBE’s stunning new CORTIS member already crowned the ‘5th Gen It Boy’ by the internet

Who is Keonho? Meet HYBE’s stunning new CORTIS member already crowned the ‘5th Gen It Boy’ by the internet

Indiatimes>>Explainers>>Trending>>Who is Keonho? Meet HYBE’s stunning new CORTIS member alread...Who is Keonho? Meet HYBE’s stunning new CORTIS member already crowned the ‘5th Gen It Boy’ by the internet Shivani Negi |  Aug 11, 2025, 09:32 IST ( Image credit : Indiatimes ) Keonho, the 16-year-old maknae of HYBE’s new boy group CORTIS, is captivating fans worldwide with his stunning visuals and natural charisma even before their official debut. Backed by talented members and fresh music, CORTIS is poised to make a bold splash in the K-pop scene.If you thought you had your eye on the next big thing in K-pop, think again because Keonho from HYBE’s fresh boy group CORTIS is rewriting the playbook. Even before their official debut, this young starlet has the internet hooked. His combination of youthful charm, jaw-dropping visuals, and undeniable stage presence is making fans everywhere stop scrolling and start obsessing. But who exactly is Keonho, and what’s the buzz all about? Let’s dive in.CORTIS drops their stunning music video GO!On August 11, 2025, CORTIS, BigHit Entertainment's new self-produced group, unveiled their pre-release single GO! along with a visually striking music video that’s been lighting up social feeds ever since. The track is a perfect teaser for the group’s style: energetic, fresh, and bursting with youthful confidence. This release precedes their official debut set for August 18, when they’ll drop their first full mini-album, COLOUR OUTSIDE THE LINES, with the title track What You Want. Fans are already loving the vibe and the group’s promise to bring something new and colourful to the K-pop world. Plus, for international fans, an English version featuring Teezo Touchdown is set for August 22, making sure no one misses out. Who’s who in CORTIS? Meet the five talented members shaping the futureCORTIS is a group of five talented young creators under BigHit Music, each adding their own unique flavour to the mix:Martin is the leader, holding the crew together with his skills and charisma. The 17-year-old Canadian-Korean artist is also credited with contributing to songs by TXT, ENHYPEN, LE SSERAFIM, and ILLIT, showing his talent not just as a performer but as a songwriter and producer.Martin of CORTIS( Image credit : Martin of CORTIS | Credit: BigHit Music )James brings a cool vibe to the group with his sharp dance moves and versatile rap skills. At 18, he’s known for his dynamic stage presence and ability to switch effortlessly between smooth and powerful performances, adding a unique flavor to CORTIS’s sound.James of CORTIS( Image credit : James of CORTIS | Credit: BigHit Music )Juhoon stands out with his impressive vocal range and emotional delivery. The 17-year-old’s expressive singing has captivated fans, and his dedication to refining his voice makes him one of the group’s strongest vocalists.Juhoon of CORTIS( Image credit : Juhoon of CORTIS | Credit: BigHit Music )Seonghyeon lights up the stage with his infectious energy and magnetic presence. Also 18, he’s praised for his captivating performances and ability to engage the crowd, making him an essential spark in CORTIS’s dynamic lineup.Seonghyeon of CORTIS( Image credit : Seonghyeon of CORTIS | Credit: BigHit Music )Keonho, the youngest member at just 16, or “maknae,” is quickly becoming the face of the group. Known for his stunning visuals and natural charisma, Keonho brings a fresh and charming energy that’s already winning hearts worldwide.Keonho of CORTIS( Image credit : Keonho of CORTIS | Credit: BigHit Music )What’s special about CORTIS is that these guys don’t just perform but also participate actively in writing, choreographing, and producing, making their music feel authentic and personal. Who is Keonho? Meet CORTIS member predicted to be the next big thing in K-popBorn Ahn Geon Ho on February 14, 2009, in Suwon, South Korea, Keonho’s journey to K-pop stardom started surprisingly outside of music. Before his trainee days, he was a top-tier swimmer, training rigorously and competing nationally. That athletic background shows in his disciplined work ethic and stage stamina today.Keonho is going viral on X for his visuals( Image credit : Keonho is going viral on X for his visuals | Credit: BigHit Music )Keonho joined BigHit Music in 2021, and it didn’t take long for fans to notice his stunning visuals and natural charm. His features often get compared to legendary K-pop visuals like Cha Eun-woo and even actor Song Kang, making him an instant favourite on social media and fan forums. Despite his young age, he carries a mature presence that makes him stand out on stage and in photos. Even his schoolmates reportedly call him a “visual king”, a title he’s clearly living up to.Why Keonho’s looks have fans totally enchantedIf you are on the K-pop side of X, you would know Keonho’s looks have fans swooning. His expressive eyes, radiant smile, and effortless charisma combine to create a magnetic presence. Fans love how his youthful innocence blends with an unexpected depth, giving him a versatile vibe that can pull off both adorable and intense concepts.IN LOVE WITH 2009 BOY.#KEONHO#건호#CORTIS#코르티스pic.twitter.com/2G3ABAw4wY— ❦ (@fileskeonho) August 10, 2025GUYS 😭#keonho#cortispic.twitter.com/snSQl00Cu0— keonho pics (@ahnkeonhopics) August 10, 2025The “😁” guy from CORTIS #KEONHO#건호#CORTIS#코르티스pic.twitter.com/0pdc4yGdS8— 건호 💧 (@Keonholocene) August 10, 2025You don't understand he's extremely handsome here 😭😭 #KEONHO#CORTISpic.twitter.com/sl4CwRYpgp— fira ^⎚ ˕ ⎚^ (@keonhomine) August 10, 2025THE 5TH GEN IT BOY 💙 #KEONHO#CORTIS#CORTIS24HourEventpic.twitter.com/FYPDIPRRjD— aj 🎨 (@cortisshinez) August 10, 2025OH KEONHO YOU WILL SOON BE ONE OF THE MAIN VISUALS OF 5TH GEN TRUST 🙂‍↕️ pic.twitter.com/iatzHZV3NL— wen 🎨 (@martinlovebot) August 10, 2025What’s even more exciting is how Keonho is more than just a pretty face. His genuine personality shines in behind-the-scenes clips and interviews, making fans feel connected. As CORTIS gears up for their big debut, Keonho's fandom is expanding, and if the past few months are any indication, this kid is well on his way to becoming a top-tier K-pop idol and fan favourite.For all the latest K-drama, K-pop, and Hallyuwood updates, keep following our coverage here. Why you shouldn’t shower right after eating: Lifestyle coach reveals the impact on digestion
Lifestyle coach Luke Coutinho advises against showering immediately after meals, as it diverts blood flow from the digestive system, potentially hindering nutrient absorption and causing discomfort. Waiting 90-120 minutes post-meal or showering beforehand allows for optimal digestion, especially beneficial for those with gut sensitivities. This simple adjustment can improve energy levels and overall gut health.
Why you shouldn’t shower right after eating: Lifestyle coach reveals the impact on digestion | - Times of India Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipesfood newstravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior Carehealth newsfitnessdietmental healthcoronavirusalternative therapiesweight lossvideosdiseasesyogaNewslifestylehealth-fitnesshealth-newsWhy you shouldn’t shower right after eating: Lifestyle coach reveals the impact on digestionTrendingKidney DamageColon CancerVitamin B12 DeficiencyKidney DiseaseBeautiful Aquarium FishesFatty LiverTamannaah BhatiaOptical IllusionEgg Cooking MethodsYellow BirdsKidney DamageColon CancerVitamin B12 DeficiencyKidney DiseaseBeautiful Aquarium FishesFatty LiverTamannaah BhatiaOptical IllusionEgg Cooking MethodsYellow BirdsKidney DamageColon CancerVitamin B12 DeficiencyKidney DiseaseBeautiful Aquarium FishesFatty LiverTamannaah BhatiaOptical IllusionEgg Cooking MethodsYellow BirdsWhy you shouldn’t shower right after eating: Lifestyle coach reveals the impact on digestionTOI Lifestyle Desk / etimes.in / Updated: Aug 11, 2025, 11:21 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeLifestyle coach Luke Coutinho advises against showering immediately after meals, as it diverts blood flow from the digestive system, potentially hindering nutrient absorption and causing discomfort. Waiting 90-120 minutes post-meal or showering beforehand allows for optimal digestion, especially beneficial for those with gut sensitivities. This simple adjustment can improve energy levels and overall gut health.  Many of us enjoy a relaxing shower after a meal, thinking it helps us feel refreshed but this everyday habit could be secretly harming your digestion. Lifestyle coach Luke Coutinho, in a recent Instagram post, warned that showering immediately after eating can interfere with the body’s natural digestive process. When you eat, your body increases blood flow to the stomach, activates digestive enzymes, and works to regulate temperature for optimal breakdown of food. Stepping into the shower too soon diverts this focus, which can be especially troublesome for those dealing with bloating, acid reflux, IBS, or sluggish digestion. The fix is simple: shower before meals or wait 90–120 minutes afterward to give your gut the time it needs to do its job efficiently.Why showering after meals affects digestionBlood flow diversionWhen you eat, your body prioritises sending blood to the stomach and intestines to break down food and absorb nutrients. A hot shower draws blood toward the skin’s surface to help regulate temperature, reducing the supply to your digestive system. A cold shower can cause the opposite, narrowing blood vessels and restricting circulation. In both cases, the stomach gets less support, slowing digestion and potentially causing discomfort.Greater impact on sensitive gutsPeople with existing gut health problems, such as gastritis, IBS, chronic acidity, or constipation are more likely to feel the negative effects. Disrupting digestion early can trigger bloating, heaviness, or acid reflux, making recovery from gut issues more difficult.Temperature regulation interferenceDigestion slightly increases your body’s core temperature. Sudden exposure to very hot or cold water forces your system to shift focus toward temperature control instead of digestion. Over time, this repeated interference could lead to poor nutrient absorption and inflammation.How to adjust your shower habits for better digestionTo protect your digestive health, it’s worth making a few simple changes to your shower routine. Ideally, take a shower before meals, especially before heavy lunches or dinners, so your body can focus entirely on breaking down food afterward. If showering before eating isn’t possible, wait at least 90–120 minutes after a meal. This window gives your stomach and intestines time to process food, release enzymes, and absorb nutrients without interference. Even if you don’t have gut issues, limiting post-meal showers to occasional situations is wise. Making this adjustment not only supports digestion but also helps maintain steady energy levels, reduces the risk of bloating, and promotes overall gut health in the long run.Benefits of waiting before showeringBetter nutrient absorption, uninterrupted blood flow ensures your body uses vitamins and minerals effectively.Reduced post-meal fatigue, avoiding a shower right after eating can help you feel less sluggish and more alert.Improved metabolism, a smoother digestive process supports balanced energy and weight management.How to make the habit change easyPlan your schedule so you shower in the morning before breakfast or later in the day well after meals.After workouts, cool down first and wait before eating or showering to avoid overlapping stress on digestion.Use the waiting period after meals for light activity such as walking, gentle stretching, or reading, these can actually enhance digestion.Summary table: Shower timing and digestionHabitRecommended ChangeWhy It HelpsShowering immediately after mealsWait 90–120 minutesKeeps blood flow focused on digestionLong hot showers post-mealReduce temperature or delayPrevents excessive vasodilationCold showers right after eatingDelay until digestion startsAvoids blood vessel constrictionShowering before eatingMaintain as a habitPrepares the body for smooth digestionShowering after meals may seem harmless, but as Luke Coutinho points out, it can subtly slow down your digestion and reduce gut health efficiency over time. This is especially important for people with sensitive digestive systems. By making a simple change, showering before meals or waiting at least 90–120 minutes afterward, you can support better nutrient absorption, reduce digestive discomfort, and keep your energy levels steady. Sometimes, it’s these small, mindful adjustments that deliver the biggest long-term health benefits.Also read| Childhood obesity linked to colon cancer risk: Why parents should take early weight gain seriouslyAbout the AuthorTOI Lifestyle DeskThe TOI Lifestyle Desk is a dynamic team of dedicated journalists who, with unwavering passion and commitment, sift through the pulse of the nation to curate a vibrant tapestry of lifestyle news for The Times of India readers. Boost liver function with this gut-friendly no-bake date bar supporting overall wellness; gastroenterologist shares easy homemade recipe
Dr. Joseph Salhab shares a recipe for no-bake date bars. These bars are a healthy alternative to store-bought sweets. They are rich in fibre, healthy fats, and antioxidants. The key ingredients include Medjool dates, nut butter, almonds, pistachios, and dark chocolate. The recipe involves layering these ingredients and chilling. These bars support digestive health, liver function, and sustained energy.
Boost liver function with this gut-friendly no-bake date bar supporting overall wellness; gastroenterologist shares easy homemade recipe | - Times of India Sign InTOIGo toTOIEtimeshomelifestylerelationshipHealth+stylevisual storiestrendingparentingSenior Livingthe artssoul searchbeautybooksrecipesfood newstravelhome & gardeneventsspotlightvideosSenior Carehealth newsfitnessdietmental healthcoronavirusalternative therapiesweight lossvideosdiseasesyogaNewslifestylehealth-fitnesshealth-newsBoost liver function with this gut-friendly no-bake date bar supporting overall wellness; gastroenterologist shares easy homemade recipeTrendingKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesKidney DamageGuava Leaf TeaFreshwater Aquarium FishesBanana BreakfastKidney DiseaseColon CancerDiabetes ManagementVitamin B12 DeficiencyHighest Inflation Rate CountriesEurope Poorest CountriesBoost liver function with this gut-friendly no-bake date bar supporting overall wellness; gastroenterologist shares easy homemade recipeTOI Lifestyle Desk / etimes.in / Updated: Aug 11, 2025, 15:23 ISTShareAA+Text SizeSmallMediumLargeDr. Joseph Salhab shares a recipe for no-bake date bars. These bars are a healthy alternative to store-bought sweets. They are rich in fibre, healthy fats, and antioxidants. The key ingredients include Medjool dates, nut butter, almonds, pistachios, and dark chocolate. The recipe involves layering these ingredients and chilling. These bars support digestive health, liver function, and sustained energy.  Craving something sweet but don’t want to derail your healthy eating plan? No-bake date bars are the perfect solution — a naturally sweet, nutrient-rich snack that’s quick to prepare and loaded with health benefits. Recently, gastroenterologist Dr Joseph Salhab shared his recipe for this wholesome dessert on Instagram, highlighting how it can be both gut-friendly and liver-supportive.By combining dates, almonds, pistachios, and dark chocolate, this recipe delivers a satisfying treat that’s high in fibre, healthy fats, and antioxidants, without the need for refined sugar or baking.Signs that all is not well with your liverWhy no-bake date bars are a healthier dessert choice; gastroenterologists explainsMost store-bought sweets are loaded with processed sugar, preservatives, and unhealthy fats. Date-based bars, on the other hand, offer a more natural alternative.Dates provide prebiotic fibre, which feeds the beneficial bacteria in your gut, helping maintain digestive health.Nuts such as almonds and pistachios supply healthy fats, protein, and essential micronutrients like vitamin E, magnesium, and zinc.Dark chocolate (70% cocoa or higher) is rich in flavonoids, powerful antioxidants that may improve heart and liver function.Dr Salhab points out that this combination not only satisfies cravings but also supports overall wellness, making these bars suitable as a snack or dessert.No-bake-date bars: Key ingredients and their nutritional benefitsMedjool dates Medjool dates are naturally sweet, eliminating the need for added sugar. They are a rich source of fibre, potassium, magnesium, and antioxidants that help regulate digestion, support energy production, and protect against oxidative stress.Nut butter Nut butters like almond or peanut butter add a creamy texture and are packed with monounsaturated fats that promote heart health. They also provide protein for satiety and muscle repair.Almonds and Pistachios Both almonds and pistachios are excellent sources of healthy fats, plant protein, vitamin E, and minerals. These nutrients support liver detoxification and help keep cholesterol levels balanced.Dark Chocolate Choosing 70% cocoa or higher ensures your chocolate is rich in flavonoids, which can help reduce inflammation, improve blood flow, and protect liver cells from damage.No-bake date bars recipe at home: Step-by-step processStep 1 – Prepare the baseRemove the pits from approximately 14 Medjool dates. Line a baking tin with parchment paper and press the dates into an even, flat layer to form the base.Step 2 – Add the creamy layerSpread ¼ cup of your favourite nut butter evenly over the date base. This acts as a binding layer while adding a smooth, rich flavour.Step 3 – Add crunch with nutsSprinkle two handfuls of almonds and one handful of pistachios over the nut butter. You can lightly crush them for an even texture or keep them whole for extra crunch.Step 4 – Melt the chocolateMelt 250g of vegan dark chocolate (preferably 70%+ cocoa) over low heat or using a double boiler. Pour the melted chocolate over the nut layer and smooth it out.Step 5 – Chill until setPlace the tin in the fridge for about 40 minutes, or until the chocolate has fully hardened.Step 6 – Slice and enjoyCut into bars of your preferred size. Store in an airtight container in the fridge and enjoy whenever you need a healthy snack.Storage tips for no-bake date bars freshnessFor maximum freshness and texture, keep your no-bake date bars in the refrigerator. The cold setting ensures the chocolate remains firm, and the nuts stay crisp. They can last up to 10–14 days when stored properly.Health benefits of eating date barsSupports digestive health – High fibre content aids digestion and promotes a healthy gut microbiome.Boosts liver function – Healthy fats and antioxidants assist in liver detoxification.Provides sustained energy – Balanced combination of carbs, fats, and protein keeps you fuller for longer.Reduces sugar cravings – Naturally sweetened with dates, reducing dependency on refined sugar.Also Read | She lost 140 kg without surgery or supplements—now a rare disease has turned her scars into a symbol of strengthAbout the AuthorTOI Lifestyle DeskThe TOI Lifestyle Desk is a dynamic team of dedicated journalists who, with unwavering passion and commitment, sift through the pulse of the nation to curate a vibrant tapestry of lifestyle news for The Times of India readers. At the TOI Lifestyle Desk, we go beyond the obvious, delving into the extraordinary. Consider us your lifestyle companion, providing a daily dose of inspiration and information.
